description:
New materials for airspace, to be used to build aerospace vehicles and other structures for space exploration. Discussion topics:

1) What is the future of the materials development?

2) What are the ways to shorten the materials development cycle?

3) Is there a way to automate the research process: remove humans from doing menial tasks, to concentrate on higher-level work?

4) How to encourage start-ups to work in the Space exploration field?

Agenda:


18:00-18:20 networking;


18:20-18:50: Keynote: Materials discovery via artificial intelligence-guided robot scientist (Pavel Nikolaev, Air Force Research Laboratory, Materials and Manufacturing Directorate, RXAS, WPAFB).

18:50-20:15: Panel:

Moderator: Michael Novikov;

Jason Dunn (co-founder & CTO, Made in Space);


Matthew Moholt (Aerostructures Branch, NASA Armstrong Flight Research Center);


Pavel Nikolaev (Air Force Research Laboratory, Materials and Manufacturing Directorate, RXAS, WPAFB);

Bill O'Connor (Innovation Strategist and Innovation Genome Project founder, Autodesk);

Dan Rasky (Space Portal Director, NASA Ames Research Center; PICA inventor);

Riley Reese (co-founder, engineering, Arevo Labs).

20:15-21:00 networking.

Speaker biographies:

Pavel Nikolaev joined Air Force Research Laboratory in 2012. Before that, he held a faculty position at the Sungkyunkwan University in Suwon, Korea [masked]) and was a Senior Scientist in the Applied Nanotechnology Program at NASA-Johnson Space Center in Houston, TX [masked]). Pavel Nikolaev was born in 1969 in Dolgoprudny, Russia. He received his B.S. and M.S. in physics from the Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology in 1993, where he studied high-temperature superconductivity. That was followed by Ph.D in physics from Rice University in Houston, TX in 1998, where he worked on carbon nanotube production techniques. His interests encompass production, processing, characterization and applications of carbon nanotubes. He has over 60 publications in refereed journals, over 30 conference presentations, 32 granted and 4 pending patents. He was the Welch Foundation Predoctorate Fellow (1994–1998); received NASA GEM ("going extra mile") award in 2004 and Rotary Stellar award in 2007.

Jason Dunn founded Made In Space in 2010 as a result of analyzing the best possible approaches to enabling a fully sustainable form of space colonization. With a core focus on space manufacturing, the company has since built, flown, and operated the first 3D printer in space. Installed on the International Space Station, the Made In Space Zero-Gravity 3D printer began space manufacturing in November, 2014. Jason serves as the Chief Technology Officer, overseeing the technical program management on projects and development of the technology roadmap for the company. Jason holds two degrees in Aerospace engineering, has studied at the Singularity University Graduate Summer Program, and is an internationally recognized speaker on the topics of space exploration and the theory of disruption. In 2014, Jason and his three co-founders were recognized by Forbes on the prestigious 30 under 30 list for manufacturing.


Matthew Moholt is a structures engineer in the Aerostructures Branch at the NASA Armstrong Flight Research Center. He has experience conducting materials and structures research in the area of composite materials and multifunctional, hot, and adaptive structures. His latest work includes the development of reconfigurable aircraft enabled via shape memory alloy materials. Mr. Moholt contributed to the development NASA's technology roadmap as a member of the Entry, Descent, and Landing team.


Bill O'Connor is an Innovation Strategist at Autodesk, working on the Corporate Strategy + Engagement team in San Francisco. He is the Founder of the Autodesk Innovation Genome Project, a 10-year project dedicated to studying the 1,000 greatest innovations in human history over the past 2.6 million years. The goal of the project is to identify, develop, and communicate powerful yet simple innovation techniques that people can use today in their day-to-day work. Bill's other areas of responsibility at Autodesk include editing the company's Autodesk POV publication, which explores big ideas in design, technology, and business; and serving as speechwriter for Autodesk's CTO and VP of Strategy. Bill has 25 years of experience working on projects at the intersection of content, business, technology, design, and culture, and has lived and worked in New York, London, Boston, and San Francisco.


Dan Rasky is an internationally recognized expert on advanced entry systems and thermal protection materials. He has developed his expertise working five years for the U.S. Air Force and more than 20 years for NASA. In the 1990's, he and his research colleagues at NASA Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, Calif., invented a heat-shield material called Phenolic Impregnated Carbon Ablator (PICA) that has subsequently been used on several NASA as well as private industry spacecraft. For this achievement, Rasky received the NASA Inventor of the Year Award for 2007 – the first ever for NASA Ames. Rasky spent considerable time at SpaceX providing expert consultation about the design and development of the heat-shield for their Dragon spacecraft. As a result, SpaceX chose PICA as the heat shield material for the spacecraft. Today, Rasky is the director and co-founder of the Space Portal at the NASA Research Park, Moffett Field, Calif. The Space Portal has a mission to "be a friendly front door for emerging and non-traditional space companies."

Riley Reese is focused on engineering research surrounding composite, high strength filament formulations and FFF machine development for high temperature operation. Riley works at Arevo Labs, a San Francisco based startup, delivering advanced materials, intelligent software, and deposition technology to make production-use composite parts. Arevo utilizes medical and aerospace-grade polymers including PEEK, PAI, and PEI, with carbon, glass, and carbon nanotube fillers to achieve specific thermal, electrical, and mechanical properties of 3D printed parts. Riley studied at UC Berkeley, where he received a B.S. in Bioengineering and Materials Science and Engineering and M.S. in Materials Science and Engineering.

We are looking for a financial sponsor of the event! (to cover speaker travel costs and food/drinks)
name: New materials for airspace

description:
** In order to attend this workshop, please register here. You'll have to show your ticket **

http://goo.gl/KDG3Hq


What is ASO?
ASO stands for App Store Optimization, and it is the process of improving the visibility of a mobile app in an app store (such as iTunes for iOS of GooglePlay for Android) and rank higher in the app store’s search results. Just like search engine optimization (SEO) is for websites, App Store Optimization (ASO) is for mobile apps.

Why is ASO so important?
The answer is easy: positioning your app is crucial if you want to succeed. Having a great app is not a guarantee for making good downloads. There are more than 40 thousand apps published each month, and standing out of the crowd is paramount. During the workshop we will talk about different ways in which you can avoid your app from becoming a zombie app.

Who's Mobincube?
Mobincube is one of the top DIY app builders on the market, trusted by 600,000 users from 220 different countries. Mobincube helps non-technical people build mobile apps for Android, iOS and WindowsPhone in a really easy way. No coding is required, yet developers can take the experience to a higher level and add their own code in order to create high-end apps. Mobincube is FREE for those who want to earn money from home, plus we offer some premium services for professionals.

Who's SensorTower?
Sensor Tower is the leading platform for app store optimization and app industry intelligence. It is actually the tool that will help you improve your app positioning with respect to your app competitors. Sensor Tower helps you take control of your marketplace visibility and gain valuable app insights about competitors and the greater app economy.

description:
In order to RSVP for this event, please sign up via eventbrite here:

http://www.eventbrite.com/e/how-to-boost-your-mobile-app-downloads-with-aso-appstore-optimization-tickets-16850794179

Brought to you by the SF Mobincube Fans Meetup group:



What is ASO?
ASO stands for App Store Optimization, and it is the process of improving the visibility of a mobile app in an app store (such as iTunes for iOS of GooglePlay for Android) and rank higher in the app store’s search results. Just like search engine optimization (SEO) is for websites, App Store Optimization (ASO) is for mobile apps.

Why is ASO so important?
The answer is easy: positioning your app is crucial if you want to succeed. Having a great app is not a guarantee for making good downloads. There are more than 40 thousand apps published each month, and standing out of the crowd is paramount. During the workshop we will talk about different ways in which you can avoid your app from becoming a zombie app.

Who's Mobincube?
Mobincube is one of the top DIY app builders on the market, trusted by 600,000 users from 220 different countries. Mobincube helps non-technical people build mobile apps for Android, iOS and WindowsPhone in a really easy way. No coding is required, yet developers can take the experience to a higher level and add their own code in order to create high-end apps. Mobincube is FREE for those who want to earn money from home, plus we offer some premium services for professionals.

Who's SensorTower?
Sensor Tower is the leading platform for app store optimization and app industry intelligence. It is actually the tool that will help you improve your app positioning with respect to your app competitors. Sensor Tower helps you take control of your marketplace visibility and gain valuable app insights about competitors and the greater app economy.

description:
Join us for the 2nd of Pacific's monthly Analytics Meetups hosted by the MS in Analytics program at Pacific's brand-new San Francisco campus.

Our personal and professional lives are set to be transformed yet again thanks to "Internet of Things." But what ‘things’ are we talking about and why is it projected that this next technological revolution will have far greater impact on our world than the original Internet?

Professor Hutley will explain what this revolution is all about and provide examples of how it is changing our lives today, and will continue to impact everything we do in the future. After explaining just how many ‘things’ can be connected to the Internet he will explain why and how these are creating the new era of Big Data and Analytics and provide insight into the economic impact these new connections will have. He will provide examples of IoT connected devices such as intelligent kitchen appliances and connected medications as well as describe how corporations the world over are transforming their business operations to take advantage of these new technologies.

Rick Hutley is Program Director and Clinical Professor of Analytics at the University of the Pacific. He is a highly seasoned Information and Communications Technologist (ICT) with a visionary outlook balanced with a practical sense of execution. With 28 years in the telecommunications / IT industry, a former CIO in British Telecom, and 14 years of executive consulting experience to the C-suites of the largest corporations in the world as the Vice President of Innovation and the Internet of Everything Solutions at Cisco Systems, he is highly experienced in driving business outcomes through the effective use of technology and data. For the last five years he has been assisting major global corporations with their adoption of the Internet of Everything, including Big Data and Analytics.
name: Let's talk about the "Internet of Things"- What it is and its Global Impact.

description:
Speaker:
Mike Conover
Senior Data Scientist, LinkedIn

Title:
Real-Time Relevance for Mobile at LinkedIn

Abstract:
This talk details patterns and processes at LinkedIn for building real-time machine learning systems to provide our members with actionable, relevant opportunities to nurture their professional networks. Featuring the Connected mobile app as an in-depth case study of how to combine compute-intensive features describing billions of relationships with information that isn’t known until the moment a user opens the app, in this talk we’ll discuss the architectural, modeling, and experimentation patterns leveraged by the Connected relevance team to rank and serve mobile content. Additionally, this session will touch on the human element of machine learning product development, outlining collaboration and communication patterns for working effectively across the organization – from reporting and documentation to evangelism, skills transfer and user experience research. Taken together, these insights will provide a detailed picture of some of LinkedIn’s best practices for building data products at a global scale.

Bio:
Mike Conover builds machine learning technologies that leverage the behavior and relationships of hundreds of millions of people. A senior data scientist at LinkedIn, Mike has a Ph.D. in complex systems analysis with a focus on information propagation in large-scale social networks. His work has appeared in the New York Times, the Wall Street Journal, Science, MIT Technology Review and on National Public Radio.
name: Speaker Series: Mike Conover | Real-Time Relevance for Mobile at LinkedIn

description:
The Privacy Innovation & Technology Meetup is thrilled to announce this month’s PI&T event: "Applied Privacy: Navigating the Uncharted Waters of Emerging Tech & Uncertain Law." Join PI&T’s first interactive workshop of the year on Thursday, May 28th with Timothy Yim, Director of Data & Privacy at the Startup Policy Lab. Enjoy this hands-on experience with drinks and light bites. Please RSVP through Meetup.com

Here’s a sneak peak:

Privacy matters. And it can matter to the tune of tens of millions of dollars and a 20-year monitoring program with the FTC. And after the net neutrality order, it matters to the FCC, an aggressive, new player in the privacy enforcement ecosystem.

On the flipside, trust, one of the goals of privacy, can be a competitive advantage that distinguishes a company from competitors, increases brand awareness, and catapults user loyalty. So why do companies keep slipping up? Often there isn’t any legal or regulatory guidance for new technology and/or new uses of data. So how do you navigate the uncharted waters of emerging tech & uncertain law?

Join our interactive workshop to find out what you should do, what your peers would do, and what regulators have done in the past. Finally, we’ll apply our newfound privacy know-how to a new emerging tech ecosystem.

Location: TRUSTe HQ: 835 Market Street, Suite 800 Contact: Matthew Coleman, [masked]

Schedule:
6:00pm - 6:30pm: Kick back and make nice with privacy professionals
6:30pm - 7:15pm: Workshop - Applied Privacy: Navigating the Uncharted Waters of Emerging Tech & Uncertain Law
7:15pm - 7:30pm: Q&A
7:30pm - 8:00pm: Continued networking

Meet our speaker: Timothy Yim
Timothy Yim, CIPP/US, CIPT, CIPM, is Director of Data & Privacy at the Startup Policy Lab, where he directs research and policy initiatives in the data privacy and emerging technology space—pushing forward data-driven policies that drive global innovation. His legal practice focuses on privacy and data security, cyberlaw, and intellectual property for startups, technology companies, and government. He sits on the IAPP Publications Advisory Board and is an IAPP KnowledgeNet Chair for the San Francisco Bay Area. He can be reached on twitter at @timothy_yim and via email at [masked].
name: Applied Privacy: Navigating Uncharted Waters of Emerging Tech & Uncertain Law

description:
Deep learning currently provides state-of-the-art performance in computer vision, natural language processing, and many other machine learning tasks. In this talk, we will learn when deep learning is useful (and when it isn't!), how to implement some simple neural networks in Python using Theano, and how to build more powerful systems using the OpenDeep package.

Our first model will be the 'hello world' of deep learning - the multilayer perceptron. This model generalizes logistic regression as your typical feed-forward neural net for classification.

Our second model will be an introduction to unsupervised learning with neural nets - the denoising auto-encoder. This model attempts to reconstruct corrupted inputs, learning a useful representation of your input data distribution that can deal with missing values.

Finally, we will explore the modularity of neural nets by implementing an image-captioning system using the the OpenDeep package.

Markus Beissinger
Recent graduate from the Jerome Fisher Program in Management and Technology dual degree program at the University of Pennsylvania (The Wharton School and the School of Engineering and Applied Science), and current Master's student in computer science. Focus on machine learning, startups, and management.
name: Intro to Deep Learning with Theano and OpenDeep

• ParkNav (Eyal Amir, CEO) - predictive analytics platform for street parking data with complete coverage of Chicago & SF in the US, and Munich & Hannover in Germany (Currently part of Microsoft Ventures accelerator in Seattle) http://parknav.com/

*Beer and appetizers from Krua Thai will be served.

description:
This event is open to anyone who identifies as a woman.

Come to this meet up ready to work on your writing, speaking, or coding and to give and get feedback from others. Let's get some stuff done!

We'll start with an intro so everyone can say what they plan to work on and what they're able give help or feedback on. We'll have resources for topic generation, talk proposals, open source projects, etc.

We'll close by talking about our goals for writing, speaking, or coding in the next month.


Venue:
Let's take a break from coffee shops this week and try working at Galvanize! We'll have free snacks and beverages available, and access to strong WIFI!

Galvanize is a coding school located at 44 Tehama St. (near 1st and Howard). Please meet in front of the building, and we'll head up the third floor together at 6pm!

If you come late, no problem -- just send a direct message to @wscsf on Twitter and someone will come let you in!

Director of Zappos Labs, Will Young and JP Mangalindan of Mashable will meet at Silicon Valley Innovation Center for a fireside chat about how Zappos views innovation in e-commerce, organization structure and company culture.

DISCOVER ways in which innovations labs can benefit companies of all shapes and sizes.

GET INSPIRED by the Zappos culture of fostering innovation.

LEARN about cutting-edge projects from Zappos Labs.

UNCOVER the future of Zappos.

GUEST SPEAKER

WILL YOUNG

Director of Zappos Labs

As the Director of Zappos Labs, Will leads the San Francisco team in exploring the future of Zappos beyond the online shopping experience. This includes creating internal tools and processes that help Zappos become a more self-organized company, developing new lines of business and experimenting in retail beyond ecommerce with experiential pop-ups.

Prior to joining the Zappos family in 2010, Will focused on creating great user experiences for more than a decade, working for leading organizations like Yodlee and Sapient Corporations and as an independent consultant. Will is also a General Partner at VegasTechFund, a seed stage investment fund started by Zappos CEO Tony Hseih, focused on empowering inspiring founders and startups passionate about building community in downtown Las Vegas.

In conversation with:

JP MANGALINDAN

Technology Reporter at Mashable

JP Mangalindan is Mashable's Technology Reporter, covering Silicon Valley businesses, people and trends. JP was a Fortune Magazine staff writer for 5 years previously, covering the intersection of business and technology. He has interviewed tech heavyweights such as Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos, Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg and Salesforce.com CEO Marc Benioff, among others.

description:
It's summer time! Which means that most of the students have returned home or gone on vacation and Berkeley is once again open for adult libations. Beta Lounge IS NOW A FULL BAR! That’s right, in addition to a great beer selection and wine by the glass, you can now get real cocktails at Beta. Beta is a hidden Berkeley treasure and is conveniently located within walking distance of the downtown Berkeley BART station. A funny thing happened when I tried to negotiate a deal with Beta, their happy hour is already very reasonable and lasts until 9 PM. The beer and wine selection rotates so for more information please see their website. I hope to see you there!

Cheers,

Rick
how_to_find_us: Although the VIP couches are reserved for us, we tend to stay at the bar.
name: Reclaiming Berkeley

description:
Wind down your week and month with us over a glass of wine! What were your successes this month? What was an epic fail? Let's talk about it and get ready for an awesome May! 5:30-6:15ish Wine Tasting, Mingling
6:15-6:30 Introductions
6:30-7:00. Quick - Fire Networking
7:00-7:30. Tell Us About It (what are you doing next that we should know about? How are you doing it? How can we help?)

There is no charge for this event other than the cost of your wine. You can do a full tasting of 6 wines for $15 or simply enjoy a glass of wine. You can also bring food with you so don't hesitate to bring dinner or snacks to go with your vino!

Campovida is open until 9pm so feel free to stay longer if you'd like!

Please be sure to bring business cards, flyers and/or any other promo tools you'd like to share with the group!

description:
Join us on Thursday, May 28 at 5:30 p.m. to indulge in food history with a Food Studies Mini Speaker Series. You will have a chance to taste local cheese and wine, mingle with other foodies and listen to Professors Alice McLean and Erica Peters. Alice McLean, Ph.D. will discuss the historical trajectory that led to a remarkable point in Asian American food culture. Erica Peters, Ph.D. will present the City by the Bay's epicurean history, resources, and people as told through its markets, restaurants, dishes, and cookbooks. This food community mini-lecture series is sure to feed the foodie in you! University of the Pacific’s Food Studies is hosting the event, which is free and open to the public. Sign-up, today!

Alice McLean, Ph.D., is a professor for University of the Pacific’s new Master of Arts in Food Studies program. Her doctorate is in English, and she specializes in food writing and feminist food studies. She has authored Aesthetic Pleasure in Twentieth-Century Women's Food Writing (Routledge, 2012); Cooking in America,[masked] (Greenwood Press, 2006); and Asian American Food Culture (Greenwood Press, 2015). In addition to books on culinary literature and American food culture, McLean writes book reviews and essays on food studies scholarships. Recent publications include a chapter on "Food and Gender Studies" for the Routledge International Handbook of Food Studies and an essay on "The Taste of Pleasure: A Review of Relational Ethics in 21st-Century Gastronomic Scholarship" for The Aristologist. In addition to her research and writing, McLean has created and taught a range of food studies seminars including Culinary Voyages; Food, Language, and the Imagination; Revolutionary Movements in the Edible Arts; Food, Sex, Pleasure in Fiction, Non-Fiction, and Film; and Eating Bodies, Consuming Cultures.


Erica J. Peters, Ph.D., is a professor for University of the Pacific’s new Master of Arts in Food Studies program. Also, she is the director of the Culinary Historians of Northern California, which she co-founded in 2004. She is the author of San Francisco: A Food Biography (Rowman & Littlefield, 2013) and Appetites and Aspirations in Vietnam: Food and Drink in the Long Nineteenth Century (AltaMira, 2012) and is the co-editor of "Food in French History," a special issue of the journal French Historical Studies (Spring 2015). Peters received her bachelor's degree in history and literature from Harvard University and her doctorate in history from the University of Chicago. She has taught at Stanford University, Santa Clara University, San Francisco State University, and the University of Maryland University College. She has published numerous articles on the history of food and drink and has presented at conferences across the United States and abroad. Peters lives in Mountain View, California.
name: Food Studies Mini Speaker Series

group.name: San Francisco Food Studies Mini Speaker Series

description:
Thinking about switching careers and becoming a software developer? Interested in learning how to code? Want to learn more about immersive bootcamps? Dev Bootcamp is a 19-week intensive program for beginners, dabblers, and those with some prior programming experience. For the inside scoop from Dev Bootcamp students, instructors, and alumni, come to our Info Session and Tour.

Hear from members of our community about why they chose Dev Bootcamp, what they learned, and what they do after Dev Bootcamp. Hear from staff and instructors about our educational style, resources, and application process. Tour our space and imagine what it would be like to come here and solve problems, build things, and learn something new.

Agenda:

5:30pm: Doors open

5:45pm-6:00pm: Tour #1 (you can take a tour before or after the Info Session)

6:00pm-7:00pm: Info Session: Panel of current students, alumni, and staff

7:00pm-7:15pm: Tour #2 (you can take a tour before or after the Info Session)

7:00pm-7:15pm: Mingle and chat

Can't make this event? Come in for a tour on Mondays from 4:00pm-6:00pm. RSVP for tours at http://devbootcamp.com/events/.

Questions? Email [masked] or visit
devbootcamp.com/faq.

Sign up for our monthly newsletter: http://eepurl.com/AgphT
name: Dev Bootcamp SF May Info Session & Tour

description:
Hi All,

I can't believe how fast time goes by, and our second monthly last Thursday meetup is happening in 2 days; on 5/28/15 at 5:15pm.

Since this is a business network and privacy is important, I decided to take it indoor in an office environment. Thanks to the generosity of the building management/Handlery Hotels, we have the conference room #311 to ourselves.

As mentioned, I prefer to have a small, tightly knit group who are real pros in the accounting profession. We are here to share knowledge; technical know-hows and principles, and best practices for our clients and on running our own businesses.

Since this is about sharing knowledge, I will lead the first few in show and tell and share knowledge. For this meetup, I will do. 20-30 minutes demo on how an experienced Quickbooks Proadvisor review / clean up a Quicknook file. We will start the meetup with short intro by all. End with guided group conversation. Reason? So that we all listen and and get to know each other real well over time.

I will provide light alcoholic beverages and beer. Please feel free to bring some. Always get ready for a show-and-tell. Educate us on your expertise. Help resolve questions/challenges members are facing. Talk about recent successes / what worked or missed opportunities and what you have learned. So that we can all learn.

See you at 515pm. Please don't be late. Once the security is gone, you might not be able to get in. Feel free to hang out till 7pm. Thanks!

Terry
name: Meetup last Thursday (5/28) at 5:15pm - show & tell & a drink near Union Square

description:
Time for Healing – Creative Meditation
Sit back, relax and be guided through a mind and body relaxation and visualization.
Leave with an increased sense of well-being, with a positive and peaceful state of mind Suitable for both beginners and those who are more experienced in meditation.

Sessions are stand alone.

Theme for Meditation include :


Experiencing Inner Silence

Discovering Self-Confidence

Overcoming Stress

Power Of A Gentle Heart

Creating a Positive Mind

Being At Peace

Meditation helps to reduce stress, and develops a sense of inner peace, joy, and strength. Join the team from the San Francisco Brahma Kumaris Center for weekly free meditation classes at Satori. The SF Brahma Kumaris Center offers a variety of programs for self development, instruction in meditation, and open their doors to all faith traditions and denominations to come and learn how to be peaceful together. They are an important member of the interfaith community of San Francisco Bay Area and promote the values of the city. Take time out of your busy day to relax and refresh with guided meditation. No reservation required. No previous meditation experience required.
name: Downtown Meditation San Francisco

description:
Shelldance Tara Circle in Pacifica invites you to dance with us in Tara’s Pure Land, at Shelldance's Lush Orchid Gardens.

Pia Hagan leads the group in the in dancing the 21 qualities of the Goddess Tara. Tara is a female Buddha, fearless, she liberates all beings.

Pia Hagan is a 3 Tara Dhatu Student Teacher, under the direction of Prema Dasara. The practice is a living, moving meditation.

Dance experience is not required, the movements are simple,
but the experience grows and deepens the longer they are practiced.
The energy that is generated is always radiated out to benefit all beings.


We welcome newcomers the last Thursday of each month from 5pm - 7pm. Afterwards we will have a small potluck.

$10 donation suggested.

Prema Dasara, the founder and spiritual director of Tara Dhatu has been declared by H.H. the 14th Dalai Lama as “a bridge between Eastern Wisdom and Western expression." For more info on Tara Dhatu go to http://www.taradhatu.org/

For more information about our regular Shelldance Tara Circle, see our webpage at
http://mutantfactory.com/shelldance-tara/dakinis-are-dancing.html

May all benefit gathered from this activity be for the empowerment of all!
May all beings have happiness and the causes of happiness,
May they be free from suffering and the causes of suffering,
May they never part from the happiness that is free from suffering,
May they rest in equanimity free from attachment and aversion.
May all be auspicious!
name: Dance The Goddess Tara in Pacifica at Shelldance Orchid Gardens

description:
Come co-work with other Meteorites during the day at Meteor Devshop, or socialize in the evening with dinner and talks. Or both. Either way, we'd love to see you!

Note: this event is for people attending Devshop in person. If you are attending the livestream, go to devshop.meteor.com to add the event to your Google Calendar.

**Doors open at 2PM.**

_____________________________________________


Meteor Devshop: Day

What: Open co-working
When: 2PM - 6PM
Where: Meteor HQ,[masked]th St., San Francisco, CA

Hack on a Meteor app, package or project. There will be plenty of snacks, caffeine, and fellow Meteorites, so please bring your laptops and ideas.

_____________________________________________


Meteor Devshop: Night

What: Dinner, Talks, and Happy Hour
When: 6PM - 10PM
Where: Meteor HQ,[masked]th St., San Francisco, CA

Come share food, drinks, and talks. Remote viewers can tune in live at devshop.meteor.com. We host featured talks that dive into technical topics or showcase interesting production case studies. We also have lightning talks where anyone can demo an app or share something useful for fellow Meteorites. If you would like to give a Lightning Talk, please sign up by the Friday before Devshop so we have time to make graphics for your name and your talk.

Sign up for lightning talks!

7:00PM - Slava Kim, Meteor core developer - "Real-time databases and Meteor: RethinkDB"

7:20PM - Lightning Talks (you!)

_____________________________________________

Transit Information There is metered street parking at this end of SOMA, but we're also pretty close to Civic Center BART station, and the Bus lines 47 and 83X take you straight here from the Caltrain stop at 4th and King. There is also a parking garage on Mission between 7th and 8th that operates until midnight. You can lock bikes to nearby parking meters.

(Videos from Devshop will be shared on videos.meteor.com. Pictures from Devshop will be shared on G+.)
name: Devshop SF - May

description:
CAMPING IN SEQUOIA NATIONAL PARK!
We have several great campsites reserved in Lodgepole campground to share with fun outdoors folks of any age. (Evening campfire banter may not be suitable for children). For those who have never been to Sequoia National Park, there are many easy hikes through the Giant Redwoods including the General Sherman tree, the most massive tree on earth. We have several other awesome hikes planned, both in the big trees and above the trees in the alpine zone. There are bathrooms nearby with flush toilets and there is a small store, laundry and showers at the campground entrance. The Marble Fork of the Kaweah River runs through the campground providing fishing and swimming opportunities. Cost will be divided equally among campers and is usually around $4 - $5 per person, per night. When you sign up, PLEASE indicate which nights you will be attending.

Parking at the campsite is limited but there is a HUGE overflow lot nearby.
There is a $20 entrance fee into Sequoia National Park.
We’ll discuss firewood as the event gets closer.
Feel free to ask questions.
IMPORTANT: Campsite information will be provided when you confirm your attendance.

As of May 4th, these people have confirmed attendance:

1. Skip +6 - 4nights

2.Eric - 4nights

3. Jake -3 nights

4. Serwah - 2 nights

5. Lauren - visiting

6. Vita - 2 nights

7. Allen - 2 nights
name: Sequoia Campsite Share!

description:
"Know Your Strengths, Own Your Strengths", with Marcus Buckingham...To express the best of yourself in life and work, you must identify and channel your unique strengths. Let's explore how we can use this information to better our own lives.

We are committed to offering women the ongoing inspiration and support to help them achieve their goals. If we talk openly about the challenges women face and work together, we can change the trajectory of women and create a better world for everyone.

We want all women to have the confidence and know-how to achieve their goals. This starts with an active and supportive community. Each day we’ll encourage an open exchange of ideas and information. We will also share Lean In Stories—short narratives of moments in life when we choose to “lean in” or “lean back” intended to inspire, teach and connect us.

Education

We offer a growing library of free online lectures on topics including leadership and communication. Produced in partnership with the Clayman Institute for Gender Studies at Stanford University and other well-known experts, these lectures offer women practical skills they can apply in their daily lives.

Circles

Lean In Circles are small groups that meet monthly to encourage and support each other in an atmosphere of confidentiality and trust. Lean In.org is recognized by the IRS as tax-exempt private operating foundation.

Guardian Angels' Lean In Circle meets the 4th Thursday of each month.

http://www.leanin.org/
name: "Know Your Strengths, Own Your Strengths"

Transitions at mid-life can leave you overwhelmed. Speaker Sharon Ascencio, founder of Ascencio Accounting Services: Money Matters, explains how to reduce overwhelm with the tasks of unfamiliar family finances -- from a practical, emotional, and spiritual perspective.


Facilitated by and featuring Pat McHenry Sullivan, founder of this Meetup and author of the forthcoming "Re-Genius Yourself: how to get back the brilliance you gave up as you grew up."

After the event, join Allison Rodman, Chapel of the Chimes Family Service Counselor, for a historical & botanical tour of this beautiful mausoleum designed by famed architect Julia Morgan. An Oakland Historic Landmark in business since 1910 providing complete end of life services; funeral home, cremation and interment.

Fun, fellowship, insights and inspiration are guaranteed.

This is the fourth monthly Lunch and Learn at the Chimes. We usually meet the 4th Tuesdays, but this month we're moving to Thursday due to the Memorial Day weekend.

RSVP to Pat Sullivan at[masked] by May 27 PLEASE.

Are you interested in increasing your business this year? BNI Dynamic Connections is an active Daly City chapter of BNI, the world's largest business referral organization. We are a group of local business owners who meet weekly to help one another promote and grow our businesses through word-of-mouth advertising and bonafide business referrals.

If referrals are an important part of your business, then this is the group for you. One advantage BNI has over other networking groups is that we only allow ONE representative from each profession to join, so that we are not in direct competition with one another. description:
Witness 3,000 pounds of glass being poured at 2200 Degrees!

Made possible by SyncFab’s Made in California Factory Tours Initiative – Take an early lunch break with fellow GIANT scale cast glass Enthusiasts at a world-class architectural and specialty glass casting studio in Oakland - the largest (20,000 sq. ft.) and earliest (1969) glass studio of its kind in North America and the Bay Area.

We will begin in the Clean Room and work our way to the Sand Blasting Area then onto Cold Working and finally the Hot Shop where we will see 3,000 pounds of hot glass being poured at 2200 Degrees. The pieces will be de-molded and put into annealing ovens to cool slowly depending on the glass thickness for a process that will last for weeks or even months. End up in John Lewis’ Gallery across the street where we will have further discussion.


John Lewis, internationally known and considered to be one of the top cast glass artists in the world, is one of the first artists to set up a hot glass studio in the Bay Area. With major commissions including the Ice Falls in Hearst Tower, the Oklahoma City Memorial, Morgan Stanley NYC, Battery Park City World Financial Center and Mikimoto in Beverly Hills - his works are also in the collections of The Boston Museum of Fine Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

NOTE: Dress for the occasion in dark work clothes with non-slip closed toed shoes. You may get a little dirty because graphite is everywhere, as it used in the molds.
name: Giant Architectural Glass Casting Tour: 3000 LBS of Glass poured at 2200 Degrees

description:
https://vimeo.com/79484859

~~~

Important Note: This is an online class that you take at your own time, at your own pace and from anywhere in the World.

Purchase Class: http://online-classes.startupsaturdays.net/product/finance-leadership-training-valuation-and-venture-capital/

~~~

Finance is a powerful global force and valuation lies at its core. Valuation makes or breaks a company. It is critical to understand valuation as an investor, entrepreneur, consultant and employee.

More than likely your next big opportunity will come form a startup or a small business and Finance lies at the core of every business success. This is the best finance class you can ever take; it will teach you how to value a business. It will give you the fundamental understanding required for successful maneuvering in the business World. Having an understanding of Finance will determine how well your business performs.

There are many circumstances in which this class is useful:

A. You are looking to raise funding for your company

B. You are looking to invest in a startup

C. You are looking to work for a startup and your success is tied to the startup’s success

D. You are about to get paid in equity

E. You are interested in selling your business

F. You are interested in learning how the World of finance works

G. You are interested in learning how to make money

H. You are interested in strengthening your skills so that you are better able to maneuver within the business world

This class is focused on startup valuation with entrepreneurial and non-public valuation needs in mind. We cover concepts such as pre-money, post money valuation and valuation equations used for private companies. We will be looking at Startup Valuation from the financial perspective. You can expect to walk away with a few equations and ideas on how to make financial projections.

This class is ideal for entrepreneurs, investors and anyone interested in working for or with a private company. Attendees to this seminar will walk away with a better understanding of the valuation process. Attendees will walk through a financial example of valuation.

Testimonials:

“This is one of the best finance classes I have ever taken.”

- Andrew

“I took the “Startup Finance Valuation” class; excellent job. This class is a must for all entrepreneurs. MBA classes do not teach how to value a startup, this class does.”

- Danny

“After taking this class I have a clear perspective on valuation. I recommend this class to all entrepreneurs. Thank you for a very informative class.”

- Bonnie

“I have been in banking for over 20 years and this class taught me valuable concepts not covered by all the classes I have taken throughout my career.”

- Yakv

</a>

~~~

description:
~~~

Important Note: This is an online class that you take at your own time, at your own pace and from anywhere in the World.

Purchase Class:

http://online-classes.startupsaturdays.net/product/microsoft-excel-training/

~~~

Excel 2011

https://vimeo.com/79914470


Excel 2013 - Class Sample:

https://vimeo.com/110946385


This is an online video training class. The best way to benefit from this class is to view all the lectures in full screen and sit through all the lectures at least once. All lectures are video lectures.

What is Microsoft Excel?

Microsoft excel is a software that allows its users the ability to find a simple solution to daily data related problems. Excel can be utilized to access most problems in a mathematical spreadsheet format. For example: Let’s say you want to manage your finances. Excel offers a solution by which a user can make a list of expenses and maintain an ongoing log of incurred expenses.

Excel offers a drawing board for daily challenges in a spreadsheet format. Excel allows its users the ability to enter data in a table format. After arranging the data in an excel sheet users are then able to perform calculations on this data for the purpose of data analysis. The type of calculations that needed to be made over hundreds of pages of paper can now be made in a single spreadsheet through Microsoft Excel.

Why learn Microsoft Excel?

There is a very valid and compelling business reason for learning Excel. However more compelling than the business reason is the value excel brings into our personal lives. Excel can serve as a decision making tool as well as a personal life management tool. Management of personal finances becomes significantly easier with the help of Microsoft Excel. Other very common uses of Excel in person life include job application management, weight management, vacation budget management, market analysis and decision analysis. On the business end, excel is essential for all business success. Microsoft Excel lies at the core of all business decision making. The charting feature of excel allows for the representation of data in a colorful format that plays an integral role in business communication. Microsoft Excel is driving Global business decisions in all types of business ranging from large corporations to small privately owned companies. Most all professionals come across Microsoft Excel at some point in their careers.

Who is this class for?

This is a beginner and intermediate level class.

Topics covered in class?

The class covers the layout of the Excel interface. During this process many of the interface features are shown in action. After the interface components are covered, the next part of the class focuses on a few of the key formulas used by Excel and the final part of the class is an example of the utilization of Excel.

Most of the components are covered during the layout overview. The overview shows how each one of these components works independently. The charting feature of excel is studied in detail with 2 chapters dedicated to this feature. The formulas portion of the class covers some of the most widely used Excel formulas.

Best way to learn from this class?

The best way to learn from this class is by revisiting the lectures and watching the lectures in full screen.

Certificate?

A certificate for this class can be earned through the completion of all the modules of the class. Certificate is delivered through email.

Time Commitment?

Students do not need to watch the complete class in a single sitting. Students have the ability to return to lectures and re-visit lectures.

</a>

~~~

Important Note: This is an online class that you take at your own time, at your own pace and from anywhere in the World.

Purchase Class:

<a href="http://online-classes.startupsaturdays.net/product/microsoft-excel-training/">http://online-classes.startupsaturdays.net/product/microsoft-excel-training/

~~~

If Master Sha does not offer a livestream event, then you can enjoy two powerful hours of soul healing teachings and blessings.

Master Shunya, Master Peggy, Master Marilyn, Master Patricia, Master Shu Chin and Master Robert are Divine Channels and Worldwide Representatives of Master Sha. They are powerful Soul Healers, Soul Teachers and Certified Divine Direct Soul Communicators with highly developed spiritual channels and the authority to read all levels of the Akashic Records—past, present and future. They also have been given the authority to remove karma associated with an issue, condition or all life. It's a rare 5th Sataurday . . . let's spend it riding China Camp. All levels welcome! Beginner/early-intermediate riders will ride counter-clockwise on the Bayview/Shoreline loop, mellow pace, rest stops and photo ops. High Intermediate and Advanced riders can pick their route . . . maybe over to the DaRk SiDe!?!?!?!

The beginner/intermediate trails in China Camp are wide single track with several switchbacks and moderate climbing . . . Int/adv routes can be very steep and challenging. Compared to Annadel the trails are smooth with very few technical/rocky areas, although there are some steep edges.

Plan on several hours for this meetup. Approximate ride time: one lap -- 1.5+ hours for beginner/int group, limitless possibilities for high int/advanced group -- 2+ hours.

Stopping for lunch on the way home is always an option.

FOR CARAVAN & CARPOOLING: Anyone wanting to carpool or caravan can meet at Johnny's Java at 8492 Gravenstein Highway in Cotati @ 9:00 AM. Comment below to make arrangements.

description:
NOTE: If you missed the "Pinnacles" 2 weeks ago; Then this is the closest thing to it. But we are even higher. It is considered by many hiking authors to be the best hike in Napa valley. (I have hidden ones that are better). But they are secret.

I have shortened it to only about 5-6 miles as it's in rugged terrain. We will meet at the crossroads & shuttle up to the state park area & start from there. It's just across from Mount Saint Helena Volcano at 4450 ft.

There are caves, old mining shafts, fantastic valley views, & unusual rock formations similar to pinnacles. But this area is very volcanic. It has the poe, poe lava flows like in Hawaii. There will be several unique rock formations to climb or photo.

We will have our wine picnic lunch at the big drop at "Table Rock". Cameras are mandatory.

Our dinner option will follow ; if you are not too tired.

This is a slightly to moderately strenuous trek. Wear good hiking shoes, hat, sunscreen & bring a light jacket.

Included are: water, Juice, tea, latte's, energy drinks, protein drinks, 30 different trail trail bars, cheese & snacks, gourmet fruit & nut packs, hiking poles, shuttles, parking lot fees, & Wine .

$25 via Check ,$, or 1 Silver eagle 1.00 coin.

Bring a lunch.

More info later. I can take 3-4 in my car from one of the pick up or Park & Ride locations.

This is a full body workout hike.
how_to_find_us: Contact Indie Tom at: boldbackroads@gmail.com    925-639-2496
name: The "Table Rock" Experience  !!

description:
Anyone who wants to carpool, meet at Orinda bart at 9:15. I will be there, maybe others too.

There are lots of plants in flower still on Mount Diablo. This is a great time to

visit falls trail, since it has north facing sections that have not dried out yet.


This is a moderate round trip of 5 miles with 1200 feet elevation
gain on the way out. It will be mostly downhill on the
return trip, and we expect to be out 5-6 hours. Bring lunch
and at least 1.5 liters of water. We will start on Clayton Oaks
trail, and proceed from there to Bruce Lee Spring trail, lower
Donner trail, and on to Wasserman and Falls trails.
Expect to see Coyote mint (Monardella douglasii) and Tincture plant (Collinsia tinctoria) in
flower, along with several paintbrush species, several Clarkia species,
Sedum radiatum, Campanula exigua, Indian Pink (Silene californica),
Chaparral pea (Pickeringia montana), California milkweed (Asclepias californica),
Phacelias, Cryptanthas, maybe Mount Diablo Jewelflower,
and lots of common plants. We should arrive back at the parking lot around 3:30
pm.

Directions: Take 24 or 680 to Ygnacio Valley Road, and continue
on Ygnacio Valley Road several miles into the city of
Clayton. At the intersection of Ygnacio Valley and Clayton
Road, turn right at the stop light onto Clayton Road. Stay on
Clayton Road past the first intersection with Marsh Creek
Road; in about a mile, Clayton Road becomes Marsh Creek
Road. Continue straight on Marsh Creek Road to Regency
Drive, where you turn right. Go 3 blocks on Regency Drive,
and then turn left on Rialto Drive. Go to the end of Rialto
Drive and park. Do not go to the end of Regency, because
that is a different access point.
name: Mount Diablo Falls Trail, Middle Trail

description:
EXPOSING HIDDEN HUNGER - Data Visualization Challenge

Bread for the World (www.bread.org) is partnering with www.HelpMeViz.com and the International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI) (www.ifpri.org) to bring together a community of data scientists, analysts, designers, dataviz developers and storytellers to help shed light on the elusive problem of hidden hunger in the developing world, specifically the mounting costs of micronutrient deficiency and obesity.

The datasets will be provided for participants to work on. Data will be made available at the beginning of the event.

PLEASE MAKE SURE YOU REGISTER HERE: http://bit.ly/1HdTfj3­

(RSVPing 'YES' ON MEETUP WILL NOT REGISTER YOU FOR THE EVENT)


There will be two data challenges:


Challenge 1: Exposing Hidden Hunger

• Using the latest global data on micronutrient deficiencies, expose the story of hidden hunger and its massive human costs.


• Demonstrate the mounting costs of hidden hunger (in lost potential, years, GDP, etc.).

• Combine data with graphic art and photos to humanize the problem of hidden hunger, giving it a name and a face.

Challenge 2: Showing How Hunger Feeds Obesity

• Use new data on obesity and body mass index (BMI) to tell the story of obesity’s stunning rise across the developing world and the array of health problems that are beginning to mount as a result.

• Find ways to count the economic and health costs of obesity as well as show the gaps in national healthcare systems being revealed by the rise in obesity.

Other Details:

Breakfast, lunch, and afternoon snacks will be provided.

Participants will also receive a printed copy of the 2016 Hunger Report, which focuses on hunger and health and will be released in November 2015.

The event will be blogged live on HelpMeViz and hosted on a Google Hangout to enable the SF and DC sites to share discoveries.

Visualizations, conversations, and comments from both coasts and elsewhere will be posted to the vizathon’s website in real time.

Register here: http://bit.ly/1HdTfj3­
name: Hidden Hunger Vizathon

description:
Get a great start on your weekend by planting trees in Oakland!

Volunteers from the San Francisco Bay Chapter have been helping Oakland continue its public tree-planting program since early 2010. We have planted over 1,250 trees so far.

What: Planting trees requested by Oakland homeowners (or schools, libraries, or parks).


Who: You and your friends. No experience is needed, and we also welcome people who aren’t Sierra Club members. We will organize you into teams of three or four, including at least one experienced planter to lead each team. You should be able to lift 30 pounds (half of the weight of a new tree). Wear closed-toed shoes, clothes that you won’t mind getting dirty, and a hat for sun protection; bring your own water and a snack. We provide the shovels, picks, brooms, and gloves.

How: Dig a hole, remove the tree from its pot and put it into the ground, backfill the soil around the roots, and sweep the sidewalk clean. Most teams can plant 3 – 5 trees in four hours. (Don't worry; we'll teach you whatever you don't know.) Other Sierra Club volunteers will do some follow-up work, such as placing a steel stake to help support a newly planted tree.

Where: The trees may be anywhere in Oakland, but first we organize into teams at[masked]nd St. in north Oakland (at Shattuck Ave, near Ashby BART). You can bike or walk to the meeting place. But if you have a car or truck, please consider bringing it to the meeting place, so you can take other volunteers and supplies to your team's planting sites.

When: Saturday mornings, 9 am to 1 pm, November through June. Join us as often as you like. Teams will leave the meeting place shortly after 9. If it is raining heavily, we won’t meet on that day.

For more information or to join our Tree Team mailing list, contact Arthur Boone, Tree Team lead, at [masked] or (510) 910-6451.
name: Plant trees in Oakland!

description:
If you're studying programming and want some company, come meet at a cafe in Berkeley.


This is a self-directed study session with no scheduled plan or leader. Sometimes it's easier to stay focused if a specific time is scheduled for studying. All skill levels and programming languages are welcome. Just bring whatever tutorials, books, courses, or projects that you're working on.


There is no fixed duration for the meetup -- I'll be there for about 3 hours, probably working on some Python.

If you're looking for ideas about what to work on, check out some of the discussions we've had at the last meetings.

If you end up on the waitlist, you can still attend. We're just a group of people working on projects at the cafe, so we can split into two groups if we can't all fit at one table.


If you don't see the group, look for a black laptop with a green Esperanto sticker on it. We're usually in the front room at a table against the wall.

Chatroom: #codeselfstudy
Forum: CodeSelfStudy.com/forum
Wiki: CodeSelfStudy.com/w
Facebook: Facebook.com/codeselfstudy

description:
Just Added to the class:

Q & A with Bay Area Commercial & Landscape photographer Joe Ercoli

What is Joe going to talk about?

The work he has put into his development as a photographer photographing commercial work, landscapes, entering print competitions, and gallery showings in the Bay Area.

Who is Joe Ercoli?

Joe Ercoli is one of the best, up and coming, Commercial and Landscape Photographers in the Bay Area. His style incorporates High Dynamic Range (HDR) and pure photographic technique, cityscapes, and an urban drama and lighting all combined.

View his work at: Anvil Image

Joe talks about one of his images:

https://youtu.be/ZM-heo_E3pY

https://youtu.be/rdYz9PaCKtA

What we have done so far

In the last 7 weeks we have covered shutter speed, aperture, ISO Metering, focal points, image design, and visual principals as they relate to the exposure triangle and the importance of an exposure value as a starting point. In Week 8 we are going revisit all the material covered.

We are also going to discuss our new roaming gallery showing for 2015. One you complete the gallery showing you will receive a C4 Certificate.

The Programs End Goal:


Present your work to a group of your peers in a public forum scheduled for Late 2015 or early 2016.
name: C4 Hayward Final Meeting- Week 8

description:
Hey Volunteers!

Join in with planting trees! No experience needed — FUF will supply tools and guidance. Wear work clothes and bring water to stay hydrated. FUF will provide coffee and pastries in the morning, and the property owners will provide refreshments when the planting is done!

What to wear/bring

• Bring water and a snack

• Bring sunglasses/hat and wear sunblock

• Wear comfortable clothes in layers and shoes

Food

This is a tree planting so there will be coffee and pastries in the morning and an owner provided potluck after. but please bring water for during the workshop.

About Freinds of the Urban Forest

Friends of the Urban Forest helps individuals and neighborhood groups plant and care for street trees and sidewalk gardens in San Francisco. This "green infrastructure" improves the city by beautifying neighborhoods, cleaning the air, raising property values and reducing polluted stormwater runoff. Since 1981, FUF has planted more than 48,000 trees, totaling 43% of the city's street tree canopy.
how_to_find_us: Generally, it's hard to miss us.
name: Tree Planting Workshop with Friends of the Urban Forest

description:
Let’s ride at the Marin Headlands!

We’ll start at Muir Beach and ride up the Middle Green Gulch Trail, then go down the Coast Trail to the beach at Tennessee Cove to take a short break and play on the beach. Then we’ll head up the Tennessee Valley Trail to the Miwok Trail, cross over Highway 1 to the Dias Ridge Trail, and work our way back down to our starting point. After the ride, we’ll regroup at the Pelican Inn for lunch.

Meet at 9am at the Muir Beach parking lot. We’ll get organized and say hello, then tires roll by 9:30. This ride will be about 14 miles with 2,400 feet of elevation gain, so it’s intermediate and there will be some good climbing.

Pelican Inn lunch menu: http://www.pelicaninn.com/food/lunch-menu/

Map: http://www.nps.gov/goga/planyourvisit/upload/map_MAHE_150429web.pdf

On May 30th the town of Port Costa is turning itself into a giant garage sale. This ride is a recreationally-paced loop of the Carquinez Strait bridges with soaring views from both sides of the water that will stop off in Port Costa for lunch and rummaging. The ride starts at the North Concord BART station around 9 a.m. and moves counter-clockwise from Martinez to Benecia, Vallejo, Port Costa, and back to BART. In total it's about 41 miles. Bring snacks. Leave no one behind.

description:
Life Drawing Workshops
Drop-in, no instructor, figure drawing workshop meets Tuesday evenings from 7 to 10 and Saturday mornings from 9 to 12. The fee is fifteen dollars for each three-hour session. The address is 3435 Cesar Chavez Studio #302 the building is located on the southeast corner at Valencia. We provide a supportive work environment with great models and a relaxed friendly atmosphere. Drawing horses, drawing boards, large worktables and some easels that are available for your use. Brush up on your drawing skills or explore new techniques. Beginner or advanced, everyone is welcome. The focus of these drawing sessions is on gesture and short poses. We work in twenty-minute sets and the length of the pose varies from one to twenty minutes.

description:
Dragon boat racing is a challenging team sport that's really taking hold in the Bay Area and beyond. It's a great way to meet people. Fifteen to forty people show up at every practice and hundreds of paddlers from around the Bay Area come out to race during the season, between March and October every year.

Find out what dragon boat racing is all about by attending a free introductory session at one of our 90-minute practices or at a New Paddler Clinic. We'll provide the boats, equipment, coaching and camaraderie for active adults who want to see what it's all about. Experience not necessary.

Practices are on Saturdays from 8:45 to 10:30 a.m. New paddlers should arrive a few minutes early for orientation and outfitting. If the weather looks iffy call our Weather Phone[masked] for a status update.

There is occasional splashing so layered, quick dry clothing is best.
how_to_find_us: The gate to our dock is behind the Nob Hill grocery store. Walk past the store towards the water and make a left. Ask for Nancy or Carolwhen you arrive.
name: Learn to Race Dragon Boats

group.name: Alameda DragonFlyers Dragon Boat Racing Club

description:
It is true that hoop dance burns lots of calories but there is so much more to it than that. Hoop dance, practiced regularly, is a gateway to transformation--not only do bodies get leaner, more coordinated and responsive, but moods lighten, stress falls away and spirits rise. Smiles appear on faces, hips loosen up and laughter bubbles up.

Hoop classes assist you in not only hooping on your waist, but hips, legs and shoulders. We also go off-body. With the hoop as our dance partner we notice more grace in our movements and begin to discover our own dance. Confidence soars as you step into your own rhythm. Hoop dance is seriously fun! Hoop dance is accessible to anyone willing to give it some time and practice. The rewards of hoop dance are countless, as far as I know. The more we hoop, the better we feel, the more we will want to hoop and the better we feel and look.


$20 drop-in fee per class or save $$ by signing up for a $60 Four-Class Package at http://goddesshoopdance.com or in-person at class. Hoops provided for class use. Wear clothes which allow for movement and bring water.

*Professional quality adult hoops available for sale at class.

Hoop dance wakes up the sacred, self-confident, sassy, sexy Goddess in you and brings you back into your own center. Oh, the things you will discover in the sacred center of your hoop! Join us! Bring your inner Goddess out to play.
how_to_find_us: Class is held in the studio in the rear of the building.
name: Goddess Hoop Dance Class

description:

**********

The San Francisco chapter of AIGA invites you to Portfolio Day.

Known as the best portfolio review on the West Coast, this is an opportunity to get valuable one-on-one feedback on your portfolio and career goals from some of the Bay Area’s best designers.

Over 100 top Bay Area designers will serve as reviewers.

This event is open to students, emerging designers, those who are returning to the profession after some time off, changing career paths or anyone looking for guidance and feedback.

You will receive multiple reviews throughout the day from experts in the field spanning a range of disciplines.

Practice your one-on-one interviewing skills with design professionals and receive valuable feedback on your portfolio.


You may bring your portfolio in book form, or load your images on a laptop and bring that with you.

There will be wifi available.

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

Portfolio Day Schedule
8:45 AM Check-In

10:00 AM Morning reviews begin
————————————————————

————————————————————
12:40 PM Lunch (lunch provided by AIGA SF)
1:40 PM Afternoon reviews begin

Afternoon breakout session: “Before, During and After the Interview” hosted by Karen Myers and Marta Fuentealba, principals of Talent Farm

4:20 PM Portfolio Day ends

After-Party at Thee Parkside
We invite you to join us at the Official Portfolio Day After Party! Continue the conversation and relax after a long day. Please head on over to Thee Parkside at 4:30 pm for some beer on us. All ages welcome, you must be over 21 to drink, and you will be carded at the door. Thee Parkside, 17th Street @ Wisconsin · San Francisco, CA

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

description:
If you HAVE QUESTIONS about the hike, or you would like to meet at the trailhead instead of carpooling, please CONTACT THE LEADER DIRECTLY at the phone number or email below. This is important because the leader might not see a message you post here.

NOTE: Our hikes are in wilderness areas where there are no facilities. Bring a lunch and liquids (2 liters or more if recommended) and extra clothing. The trails may be steep, rough, narrow, or slippery. Wear hiking boots with good traction. Trekking poles are often helpful. Bring a hat, sunglasses, and use sunscreen.

Please ARRIVE EARLY at the carpool location. The time given is our DEPARTURE time. Carpool expenses are shared.

We ask for a mere $10 per year in membership dues. There is no "per hike" fee. You are welcome to join us for free on your first hike.

To pay the $10 Annual Dues, please visit our Website: http://haywardhikers.weebly.com . Click on "Join or Renew". Credit/Debit/Paypal is accepted, or check by mail. Thanks!

description:
Been wanting to do this again for awhile now. Met some great professionals last time we organized a hike. The 40 plus hour a week desk job has become the new "smoking" which makes it ESSENTIAL to MAKE time for working out. Making time for yourself to exercise is something a lot of us tend to push to the side, its something we tend to see as something we should do, not something we must. We rarely do what we should do but always do what we must so knowing that, exercise has to be something we feel like we must do, 510 Hikers is the place to reinvent how you spend your Saturday morning and become your Saturday morning "must" do. We consistently bring 100 plus active Black Professionals out EACH WEEK to challenge, support, encourage and share. The hike group has encouraged thousands to get on the trails, nothing like sunshine, mother nature and tons of smiling faces to bask in. This week hike is 5.4 miles and we follow that up with an optional 10 minute yoga session/stretch.

Please bring at least 24oz of water (actually a sports drink will be even better). No water, no hike (this is not the hike to walk with your Starbucks Latte, we work on the trails and we want to burn calories). KIND sponsors the entire team so there will be plenty of free KIND bars, but please bring a couple snacks to offer quick energy boosts when feeling depleted. Also, please come on time, I know, I know, trust me, we start on time, don't want to leave anyone. Parking is metered, please bring quarters or credit cards to feed the meter (you will want two hours).

Feel free to bring kids, n strollers please, however, if your kid can hang, great, we have usually 5/6 of them every hike so don't let you child convince you to leave them home in front of the Playstation, bring them!!!!
name: 510 Hikers meets East Bay Black Professionals!!

description:
-Alamere Falls Hike-

CARPOOL LINK 2 Spots IKEA in Emeryville at 4400 Shellmound, or Shopping Center at 16th & Portrero in SF

The Meetup Spot: (Trailhead) Meet at Trailhead at 9:15am.

Carpool Fee from SF is $10. We will meet PaloMarin Trailhead (end of Mesa Rd in Point Reyes, Ca). This is a winding road with cyclists. Please allow plenty of time for driving. Park on the left-hand side of the road. We will gather at the trail head in the parking lot.

The Hike Plan:

Alamere Falls has to be one of my favorite hikes in the bay area. You start from the Palomarin Trail Head-Alamere Falls (check the parking signs -- they will give you a ticket!). The hike to Alamere takes you along the coast trail with some spectacular views, then inland through the forested area, the past Bass Lake which you can check out and finally to the Falls. The hike down to the falls is not maintained and pretty much just all loose slate, so wear some aggressive tread or be prepared to slip and fall (and if you do, don't worry, you wont be the only one :)). Finally getting to the beach and looking up at the falls is truly magical. Check the weather first and make sure to go on a fully sunny day for the best experience. I'd say this is moderate difficulty and is great for couples, groups, or just solo.

What to bring:

Good hiking boots/shoes; hat; sunscreen; backpack, at least 1 liter of water and camera too, if you’re a photog. DRESS IN LAYERS and wear long pants! Weather can be unpredictable, so have layers that you can shed. Food to eat; there is no food for purchase along the way. Consider…dried fruit/nuts/seeds, chips, dips, salsa, wraps, meats/cheeses, sliced sandwiches, salads, cheese/crackers, - be creative!

Tips for an enjoyable hike:

• Carry more water than you than you think you’ll drink – 2 liters is best.

• Fill your water bottles half way night prior, then top off in the am.

• Bring a paper or plastic bag for your trash. Pack it in-pack it out. We don’t leave trash on the trail.

• Bring some cash for a possible post-hike lunch.

• Bring post hiking shoes. Your feet will thank you.
name: -Alamere Falls Hike-

description: Surfing, without a doubt, is good for the body and soul. However, surfing early in the morning has its added benefits. Being out here at dawn allows you to enjoy better conditions…less wind providing for glassier waves. You’ll have peace of mind knowing that there are far less people to have to dodge when catching a wave. Finally, you come out energized, feeling accomplished, and ready to take on the rest of the day. See for yourself ; )
name: Get Hooked on Dawn Patrol! (TBD)

The Public Works SF + IN·SIGHT Present:
Max Cooper - Emergence A/V Set (Traum/FIELDS)
+ Simon Baker (Drumcode/True Soul)
+ Mossmoss (As You Like It)
+ Matt Hubert (In:Sight)

Robot Ears Loft with
+David Gtronic (Kina, Suara, Monique, Serkal // Berlin)
+Chad Andrew (Kina, Dissonant, Serkal // Berlin)
+Loui Vanhard (Robot Ears, Q Underground)
+ Amber Cox/Slumber (Robot Ears, Yuma Recordings)

Max Cooper buzz.

RA top 20 live act of 2013 and 2012, top 100 DJ 2011

"Incredibly intense" - Pitchfork

"Insanely good" - The FADER

"Impossibly gorgeous" - FACT

"Ace" - theQuietus

"Wants you to dance and cry simultaneously, and will probably succeed in doing so" - DUMMY

"A religious experience .. a master at blending blissed-out, lightweight textures with moments of heavy darkness" - Earmilk

"Recalls Philip Glass, Aphex Twin's most serene moments and even Henryk Gorecki's Symphony No. 3" - Resident Advisor

"A quiet elegance that's unique to the genre" - XLR8R

"Some of the more ambitious and exploratory music crafted within the last few years" - The Music Ninja

"One of today's most innovative electronic musicians" - DJZ

David Gtronic

There are many techno producers whose works are devoid of the subtleties that would suggest a wider musical competency and understanding. Then there are those whose grooves are infused with painstakingly produced little details and a sense of wonderment that reaches beyond beyond mere dancefloor functionality. Whether he’s producing thumping techno or downtempo chillout, David Gtronic’s sense of musicality always shines through.

He is largely known for what he likes to term “aggressive”, hard grooving techno - but it’s those obscured flourishes of organic elements that colour his sound which really set him apart from the pack. Captivating releases that he’s released on labels such as Suara, Monique Musique, Kina Music, Serkal, Oblack and Moan Recordings and remixes for the likes of Santos and Yaya have found support from the likes of techno deities including Richie Hawtin, Marco Carola, Loco Dice and Dubfire. His Terrace Podcast has grown since launching in August 2008 to reach almost 1,000,000 downloads in total, showcasing his eclectic and carefully-crafted journey-style DJ sets to listeners across the world. Whatever he puts his hands to, it’s always imbued with the sense of musical mysticism and contrast between the natural and the artificial that he strives to bring to life. David relishes the challenge of crafting techno that reveals itself gradually to the careful listener, emotions embossed into his pounding rhythms by way of subtle textures and melodies that lay deep beneath the surface. His mesmerising collaborative mini-album with Dutch producer Lilith, Lagrimas Del Sol, recently demonstrated his prowess in marrying eclectic, traditional sounds to complex dancefloor grooves, with pianos, cellos and much more woven into this fascinating musical tapestry. Created over the course of several months between their respective homes of Miami and Amsterdam and working with some of Europe’s most revered session musicians, it represented a new high in his career arc and boldly underlined his desire to create sonic artefacts that set themselves apart from run-of-the-mill formulaic dance music. With his more recent EP alongside Romanian stars Livio & Roby and his collaboration with Santos, David Gtronic’s stock has risen further still, with each release continuing to cement his reputation as one of techno’s more adventurous and musically-minded producers.
name: Max Cooper, Simon Baker, David Gtronic & Chad Andrew @ Public Works

description:
I'm scheduling this one so early because tickets went on sale today (2/13) and this will probably sell out at some point.

Those of you who are familiar with Wire know what's what, and they are great playing live.

If you don't know Wire, they've been around since about 1977; hard to describe them, but they play highly intelligent, angular, jagged post-punk music, and often with truly lovely melodies. I can't think of anybody else who could have gotten a 'hit' record in England with a song about aerial cartography, and a beautiful song it is, too.

I never got to see 'em in the Old Daze, but since 2000, I've seen them 6 or 7 times at various venues around San Francisco - awesome stuff!!!

The show is at 9:00, and tickets are $25 + $4 service. Let me know if you have any questions about the meetup or about Wire - Cheers!! Larry.
how_to_find_us: TBD as the date approaches...
name: Let's go see Wire at Slim's!!!!

description:
NOTE: This event is EVERY FRIDAY!! Signup is at 8:30PM - YOU MUST ARRIVE BEFORE 9PM TO PLAY IN THE GAMES.


We will be joining the international travelers group - here is the main event link: http://www.meetup.com/SanFranciscoHostel/events/220819213/

They will place you on a team based on your country and your team will rotate around the room & play beer pong, flip cup, and relays against the other teams. ***The point of this event is to meet the others in the room while competing, then finish the night in the dance/club part of the venue.

Come join us, have some drinks, and meet some new people. When you arrive, tell the girl at the door you're with the meet up if you'd like to be teammates with others in the group. RSVP is *required* for planning purposes. Thanks!

Here's the INFO:

We do a weekly tournament on Fridays - we mainly get about 50-60 backpackers who are staying at hostels around the city, along with locals who want to meet new people and share travel stories.

FREE to play! FREE entry before 9:30PM with a drink special purchase and RSVP!

Drink Special: 5 BEERS or 5 CUPS of WINE for $10 before 9PM; 5 for $15 from 9-9:30PM, 5 for $20 after 9:30PM.

Spirit Special: $2.50 Wells from Midnight to 12:30AM! (Wells = Any House Spirit with a mixer).

Win Prizes!
Games: Beer Pong, Flip Cup, Relays


--> Everyone's placed on a team based on your country (to make it easy to meet people).
--> Teams compete at flip cup, relays, and beer pong.
--> Play -or- just watch, drink cheap beer and be social!

Meet & compete against travelers, locals, au pairs and students!

'Like' us on Facebook *and* RSVP that you're attending & get a $1 shot!
LIKE US HERE: https://www.facebook.com/beerpubcrawl
RSVP HERE: https://www.facebook.com/beerpubcrawl/events

WHERE: HORIZON LOUNGE - 498 Broadway St, near the corner of Kearny St & Broadway
(Signup with the Beer Olympics coordinator)
TIME: Signup at 8:30PM - Be sure to arrive by 9PM to play!

description:
NOTE: This event is EVERY FRIDAY!! Signup is at 8:30PM - YOU MUST ARRIVE BEFORE 9PM TO PLAY IN THE GAMES.


We will be joining the international travelers group - here is the main event link: http://www.meetup.com/SanFranciscoHostel/events/220819213/

They will place you on a team based on your country and your team will rotate around the room & play beer pong, flip cup, and relays against the other teams. ***The point of this event is to meet the others in the room while competing, then finish the night in the dance/club part of the venue.

Come join us, have some drinks, and meet some new people. When you arrive, tell the girl at the door you're with the meet up if you'd like to be teammates with others in the group. RSVP is *required* for planning purposes. Thanks!

Here's the INFO:

We do a weekly tournament on Fridays - we mainly get about 50-60 backpackers who are staying at hostels around the city, along with locals who want to meet new people and share travel stories.

FREE to play! FREE entry before 9:30PM with a drink special purchase and RSVP!

Drink Special: 5 BEERS or 5 CUPS of WINE for $10 before 9PM; 5 for $15 from 9-9:30PM, 5 for $20 after 9:30PM.

Spirit Special: $2.50 Wells from Midnight to 12:30AM! (Wells = Any House Spirit with a mixer).

Win Prizes!
Games: Beer Pong, Flip Cup, Relays


--> Everyone's placed on a team based on your country (to make it easy to meet people).
--> Teams compete at flip cup, relays, and beer pong.
--> Play -or- just watch, drink cheap beer and be social!

Meet & compete against travelers, locals, au pairs and students!

'Like' us on Facebook *and* RSVP that you're attending & get a $1 shot!
LIKE US HERE: https://www.facebook.com/beerpubcrawl
RSVP HERE: https://www.facebook.com/beerpubcrawl/events

******************************************************
WHEN: EVERY FRIDAY!!
WHERE: HORIZON LOUNGE - 498 Broadway St, near the corner of Kearny St & Broadway
(Signup with the Beer Olympics coordinator)
TIME: Signup at 8:30PM - Be sure to arrive by 9PM to play!
******************************************************
