description:
Brief Introduction

This is a meet up group for people who are interested in playing badminton, making friends who love badminton. Single, doubles or all skills levels are welcome. I am organising this group because I realize that more and more people are falling in love with this game in Califonia. I am new to this country and Bay Area. I hope to meet new friends to enjoy this game together and make a healthier body through doing this sport. So, shoot me a message and let's start connecting.

Norms

I ) Bring your own shuttlecocks to the badminton meetup.

2) Pay the admission at the reception

3) Announce the court number on the discussion forum if you get there early. Check the forum where the group is if you cannot find us.

About Diversity

As the Fri group is expanding, I would like to re-clarify the idea of "diversity" in a more detailed way, because I think we have enough capacity (10+people) to be able to accommodate people from all different sorts of badminton levels and social cultural backgrounds and make sure every single one is having fun. So, I would encourage people to use your best emotional intelligence and judgement to find time to play with the people who has a lower level than you for whatever period of time that is available to you. Say, if you think you are an advanced/intermediate level player, please spend some time with intermediate/ beginning level players 1) intentionally reach out or 2)whenever you want to take a break from finishing some exhausting games, or 3) you notice beginner players (they have fewer resources ) are "lonely". Whatever ways you feel resonate with. But, (Important!) you do not have to sacrifice your own play rhythm and time for taking care of others.

This is probably not within your comfort zone and it might not be able to maximize the enjoyment of getting the competitiveness of the game. However, I would invite members to challenge themselves a little bit and find different ways of enjoying badminton through playing with various people. If you have difficulties to make that happen, or you do not feel comfortable with that idea, that is also understandable and worth being well respected. I want to honor that diversity piece too. We do not judge people on that too. ☺☺
how_to_find_us: Will announce the court number on forum. If you cannot find the court  phone Mihir at  4088393476

description:
Note: Showtime is 3 PM. Running time is 86 minutes. Tickets are $15 general, $14 for students/seniors available at the festival website. Cheaper tickets can be obtained by getting Festival Pass or a 6 Pack.

The San Francisco Green Film Festival is a film festival with an environmental focus, showing films and documentaries that offer a unique perspective on the most pressing environmental issues. Films’ topics include: water in the West, better cities, nature and biodiversity, zero waste, and more. The 4th edition runs from May 28 to June 3.

Change is afoot in city of Datong in Northern China. Controversial Communist Party Mayor Geng Yanbo is pulling down one of the world's dirtiest cities to recreate its glorious past. He’s determined to transform his coal-mine city into a tourism haven for clean economy. But to achieve that, he needs to pull down 140,000 households and relocate 500,000 residents to give way for the restoration of the ancient city. Can damaging individuals' interests be justified so that future generations can enjoy a sustainable Datong? Filmmaker Zhou Hao, gives you remarkable access to the inner workings of Chinese government in this current events documentary.

Producer Zhao Qi will be present for discussion.


Winner of World Cinema Documentary Special Jury Award for Unparalleled Access at 2015 Sundance Film Festival

Trailer:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ouUnnpQykcY

Reviews:

"offers a fascinating verite portrait of the collision between progress, politics, corruption and citizens’ rights in a rapidly changing People’s Republic" - Dennis Harvey, Variety

"At once a fascinating and shocking cautionary tale" - Boyd van Hoeij, The Hollywood Reporter

"plays out like an episode of Parks and Recreation directed by the Maysles brothers." - Christopher Gray, Slant Magazine
name: SF Green Film Fest: The Chinese Mayor (Zhou Hao, China, 2015)

description:
Next Sunday we'll enjoy a serene hike through Tilden Regional Park, which offers some of the most breathtaking 360 views of the Bay - from Marin to Mt. Diablo.


The trail is 5.5 miles long and should take approximately 2.5 hours to complete. There are a few vista points with picnic tables along the way for us to stop for rest, rehydration, and to take in the views. I would rate the trail easy to moderate, with about 70% level and downhill, and 30% a steady, but modest, incline. Good for beginners and intermediates!

Please arrive at the parking lot at 1:45 p.m. so that we can begin the hike promptly at 2 p.m.

Remember to bring water!

Directions: If you're heading northwest on Grizzly Peak Rd, take a right onto Lomas Cantadas Rd (you should see a sign that says Redwood Valley Railway and trains). Immediately veer left at the split and go past the railway parking lot on your left. Just ahead there will be another split - veer right and the parking lot where we'll meet will be on your left.

Looking forward to seeing you there!
name: Bayview Hike in Tilden Regional Park

description:
The Savage Frontier, the Barbaric North, the Wildlands. These, among many others, are nicknames for the North. It attracts adventurers and settlers. Adventurers delve into the cavernous wreckage of dwarven and drow strongholds and explore mysterious ruins of ancient cultures, while settlers look for new and untamed lands - untrampled by human footsteps - to eke out an existence unfettered by laws, taxes, and the prying eyes and gossipy mouths of nosy neighbors.

Our story begins with a delegation from the dwarven city of Mirabar bound for Waterdeep, the City of Splendors, mysteriously disappearing in a valley deep in the Savage Frontier. Among the missing: a renowned dwarven historian and his collection of ancient manuscripts; three diplomats, each carrying a coded document; important spell components for the creation of a powerful and magical grove; and lastly, a body of a fallen knight to be interred with honor with the Knights of Samular.

Three heroes have arrived to tackle the mystery:

Enna: the half-elven ranger who long ago woke up in a forest with amnesia, starving and bruised. With her panther as her pet companion, she was raised by her elven and half-elven parents. Her only clue to her past: a strange map of a long-forgotten dwarven stronghold beneath the Sumber Hills.

Liam Wolfheart: cleric of Chauntea and merchant of the Wolfheart Shipping & Brewing Co. of Neverwinter. His father’s ship fell under attack on the Trackless Sea by the nefarious Gar Shatterkeel. With most of his crew lost, Liam and his ally Cirdon have tracked Shatterkeel to a frontier valley north of Waterdeep.

Their alliance will collide with a fourth hero who arrived in the frontier town of Red Larch shortly after the three left town in search of the delegation:

Ozeer yn Ibbram: a mercenary of Cormyr, born in the lush grasslands of the Border Kingdoms in southern Faerûn. Having never known his mother and with his father falling to a plague, Ozeer lived a life fighting in a variety of petty local wars. Setting out on his own, his journey has taken him north, where rumors of a group of sell swords occupy a keep in the Dessarin Valley.

Not until events that have yet to unfold will draw the companions deeper into the shadows, forever changing their lives and shaping the fate of the world. No one expected them to be heroes. Least of all, themselves.

Princes of the Apocalypse is a Dungeons & Dragons 5th edition adventure held monthly in the Outer Richmond District of San Francisco.
name: Princes of the Apocalypse – Game Session #2

description:
I am not earning enough to cover meetup.com's organizer dues, so this will be the LAST FORAGING CLASS EVER I will teach through this website.

If I continue to teach classes, I will announce them on my personal website; AncestralArts.net.

Thanks to everyone who have come to meetups so far to help support the group!

This group will be deleted when I do not pay the dues next month.

LOCATION: Meet at the parking lot by the Strawberry Canyon fire trail. It is on Centennial drive, just downhill from the UC Berkeley Botanical Garden and just uphill from the Strawberry Canyon Pool. Paid parking is available at the latter areas if the former lot is full (both are ~5 min walk).

$20 cash per person.

We will meet Saturday at 1 PM and take a 2.5 hour walk along trails while I teach you about every edible and useful plant in the area.

You will learn how to ID and use over 60 species of wild, native or introduced plants, such as edible greens, seasonal nuts and fruits, edible roots, medicinal herbs, plants for cordage and soap, etc.

Depending on our luck, we will also find some insects, other animals, and fungi for which you will learn traditional uses.

Much of the information you will learn is not found in any field guides or edible wild plants books. Almost everything I teach is based on my graduate research at UC Berkeley of historical California Indians; first-hand accounts of their cultures that are mostly not available to the public.

The main focus is edible species, but you'll also learn about medicinal and technological uses.

You are welcomed to point out any plant, animal, or fungus to learn to identify it and its uses.

I suggest bringing a notebook, pencil, and camera to record species info.
name: LAST FORAGING CLASS EVER

description:
Join us on a nice Sunday in The City with the 1:00 PM showing of Book of Mormon,

We'll figure out plans for sight-seeing and dinner following the show.

Tickets


Be sure to buy your tickets early ($80 - 255). This will sell out soon.

Buy your tickets online here and select "The Book of Mormon", then find tickets for May 31st at 1:00 PM.

Unfortunately we likely won't be able to sit together.

BART and Gathering

Many of us will meet at Colleen's home at 10:00 AM in Stockton, then carpool from there to BART. The venue is a block from a BART station.

Stockton to BART (Dublin/Pleasanton): We'll leave Colleen's at 10:15 AM. This is a 47 minute drive to 5801 Owens Drive, Pleasanton.

BART Dublin/Pleasanton to Civic Center: The train leaves BART at 11:21 AM and arrives at Civic Center at 12:10 PM. If we miss this one, the next train is in 20 minutes. BART is about $12 round trip, and tickets can be purchased via cash/CC at the station.

Can't find the group? Text David at[masked]-0651.

Tip: Eat a big breakfast before you leave!

Early Dinner after the Show

The show will end at about 3:30 PM.

Let's eat at the Ferry Building Marketplace. We'll take BART Civic Center to BART Embarcadero. There's plenty of great dining choices at the Ferry Building.
name: Book of Mormon Broadway Show (SF)

WE ARE NOW AT MAXIMUM CAPACITY FOR THIS CEREMONY. PLEASE DO NOT RSVP THAT YOU ARE COMING. Thank you

Please join us for the creation of a beautiful Apacheta in Sausalito, CA.

We will gather in ceremony to create an apacheta for the Temple of Inana. All mesa carriers, family and friends are welcome. Please bring at least one stone relative with you to be incorporated into the apacheta. Larger stone relatives are greatly appreciated.


If you have flowers, feather or crystal that wants to be offered to the apacheta, bring them to embellish the beauty. Please bring your children to participate. They are sweet medicine.


Sacred music will be led by Alex Kugler. Please bring your music makers and voices.


There is free street parking, yet due to narrow streets, carpooling is recommended to avoid a steep climb. There are several stairs to reach the garden from the street.


Large stones can be dropped off at mailbox in front, before you find nearby parking. Bring a water bottle with lid. Snacks will be provided.

description:
We will meet at Viano Vineyards in Martinez for a wine tasting session. It would be great for each person to being an appatizer to share. The cost is $8.00 per person and you get 4 tastings and get to keep the glass. Here is a little more about Viano Wineyards. www.vianowineyards.com

Viano Winery

Our century-old vineyard is nestled on hillsides surrounding a fertile little valley where cooling breezes from the Carquinez Straits provide the necessary balance of heat and coolness. Here in our valley, we have a proven combination of ideal soil and climatic conditions favorable for growing premium wine grapes. Included are Chardonnay, Chenin Blanc, French Columbard, Muscat Canelli, Cabernet Sauvignon, Gamay, Petite Sirah, Sangiovese and Zinfandel.

This Family Estate, now with its 3rd and 4th generations, was founded by the Viano family in 1920. They purchased the already planted vineyard which was established in 1888. It reminded them of their vineyards in Piedmont, Italy. This area, once so rich in grapes, was named Vine Hill and home to more than 15 wineries.

Some of the original vines still remain while the balance of the vineyard has been expanded and replanted to keep up with new world tastes and desires. Using the most natural, cultural practices possible, combined with traditional winemaking techniques, which includes natural yeast and aging in small oak cooperage, we bring you these fine handcrafted wines.

Viano wines are produced, bottled, and marketed directly. Because of this, Viano wines offer exceptional quality and value. For additional savings on our great wines check our specials section on our price list frequently.

description:
1927 Arthur Eddington gave the Gifford Lectures. Eddington begins, "I have settled down to the task of writing these lectures and have drawn up my chairs to my two tables. Two tables! Yes; there are duplicates of every object about me - two tables, two chairs, two pens." One table is substantive, relatively permanent, has a certain color, etc. This is the everyday table. The other table is mostly empty space, has many parts which are electrically charged, etc. This is the scientific table. Graham Harman takes Eddington's lecture as his point of departure in his paper "The Third Table." Harman claims that a critical element is missing in this seemingly overpopulated account of the one table as being two tables, an everyday and scientific table. The problem is that these are both ways in which the table appears to us. They are images in the mind; they're not real. There must be a third table, one which lies deeper than the everyday and scientific images. Eddington's two ways of accounting for phenomena is given an influential contemporary articulation in Wilfrid Sellars ideas of the manifest image and the scientific images. Come and join our tables as we delve into this great debate which spans from the philosophy of science to the philosophy of art.


This is round 2 of this topic. We'll focus much more on the Wilfred Sellars reading this time around.

Wilfrid Sellars, Science, Perception, and Reality, Chapter 1


Arthur Eddington's 1927 Gifford Lecture, Preface and Intro


Graham Harman, "The Third Table"
name: Round 2: Perception & Reality of the Scientific, the Artistic, and the Everyday

description:
This is a duplicate of the other Tilden Park 2B Hike, scheduled the same day at 11:00 am. This will be a second group, an hour later, with different leadership, to accommodate the extraordinary number of people who have expressed interest in the original hike. Expect the parking lot to be full. You can park on the shoulder of the road, but be sure to park completely out of the road, or you can be cited.

Experience the varied terrain of Tilden Park, from canyon to ridge top, with views of the Bay on one side and reservoirs on the other. Pace will be moderate to moderately brisk. Elevation gain is about 1,600 feet over a distance of about 7 miles. Although this event is not planned as a “canine hike”, well-behaved dogs will be permitted. EBRPD rules require dogs to be on leash within 200 feet of any trailhead and all waste must be removed from trails.

See trail map of our route at www.sfeinberg.com/MapB2 .
(To print trail map: If you use a browser that relies on a non-Adobe PDF program, and if the map does not display properly with the route marked in color, then save the map file and open it in Adobe Reader. Then, in the print dialog box, select “Fit” under Page Sizing & Handling and select “Landscape” orientation.)

CANCELLATION: Rain shortens or alters. Event is held rain or shine.

BRING: lunch and at least one liter (2 standard bottles) of water; hiking boots recommended.

DIRECTIONS: Take Orinda exit from Highway 24 and head northwest on Camino Pablo, nearly 2 miles to traffic light at intersection with Wildcat Canyon and Bear Creek Roads; turn left on Wildcat Canyon Road; go roughly two miles to Inspiration Point, on right.

description:
We are going to a wine tasting at Pichetti winery followed by a hike around the Pichetti ranch, where peacocks apparently roam free.


Pichetti winery was established in 1890, and is one of the oldest wineries in California. They offer a $10 tasting of 5 wines, and $5 of the tasting goes towards your purchase of a bottle. Not bad!


They also have a large picnic area with tables for us to relax and to enjoy the wine. It sounds like a great way to spend a sunny Sunday afternoon.

The Plan:

12:00 PM: Meet at the picnic tables outside the tasting room
12:30 PM: Taste the wines
01:00 PM: Start the hike
02:30 PM: Wine break!
04:00 PM: Back to the winery for some relaxation
05:00 PM: Dinner in Sunnyvale?

Getting there:

There's no public transportation so cars will be needed. Please fill out the carpool spreadsheet so we can coordinate rides.

http://goo.gl/forms/K9kEkFd2A9


What to bring:

This is a real hike so bring whatever hiking gear you normally use. Remember to bring:

• Water


• Hiking/walking shoes


• Comfortable clothing (it may get hot or chilly)


Optional:

• Backpack


• Hat, sunglasses, sunblock


• Snacks


• Wine


After the hike:

The winery closes at 5 pm so we'll have to leave no matter what. If people want to get dinner, we can go to 99 Chicken which is my favorite Korean Fried Chicken place in the Bay Area.
name: [Cupertino] Wine tasting and hike at Pichetti winery [$10]

description:
Hello Lovely Ladies,

What: This event will be a very intentional day of healing. I will be leading a 5 mile hike where we will do different rituals, set intentions, release blockages and ask for support. I did this event just a few weeks ago and it was incredibly powerful for me in letting go of hurtful events in the past. I would love to share this with other women who would like some support on moving through the past, letting go, healing and setting some powerful intentions about what they would like to create for themselves.

Where: We will meet at the Marina Green in San Francisco and carpool together. I will be driving and I have a couple other ladies who have also offered to drive as well.

Details: We will decide and confirm on who is riding in whose car when it gets closer to the date. If you plan to attend please post your e-mail address so I can send you more specific details about how to prepare for the event. This event is going to be absolutely amazing, I can feel it. Come ready to experience some magic, to feel blocks lifted and to experience some new energy in your life.

Cost: The cost of this event is $30 for the whole day paid directly to me. The reason I am charging a fee is because I am leading this intentional event, holding space for healing, and will be doing energy work during the rituals. :) yay!


Please message me if you would like more details!

description:
Hi! This is a great dog friendly hike. We will have lunch after at Sanchos Taqueria. In RWC about 3 miles away. Here is a link to Sanchos http://sanchostaqueria.com. This will be a large group hike as that it is co listed on the SJ Campbell Anything Fun Group http://www.meetup.com/hiking-297/

This location is great for Peninsula hikes...dusty a bit this time of year and minimal poison oak. We will take a longer hike that wraps around the ridge of the reserve "The Dusty Footed Wood Rat Trail" close to 280. There is elevation change up to 800 -1000 feet. Not over the top difficult...but moderate to challenging in some places as you hike down and back up. We will do several short rests

Pulgas Ridge Open Space Reserve is a 366 acre site across from Edgewood Park. You will completely enjoy the breath taking views of the peninsula and bay.

Lots of fun and dog friendly.

Please make sure your in condition and can hike 5 miles with some steep elevation changes.

description:
Hike Duration: Approx. 2 hours and 30 minutes
Difficulty: Easy to moderate
The route from Ocean Beach to Land's End and along the coast to the Presidio. The views from this trail will keep you breathless, ranging from rugged beach to the old Sutro Baths, to hills alive with wildflowers and twisted cypress trees, and even some great neighborhoods.

Meet Point: Trouble Coffee & Coconut Club (4033 Judah St.).
Departure Time: 11:15AM
We will walk the three blocks and cross over the Great Highway amid the dunes of Ocean Beach. Head north toward Cliff House. Mosey on to Land's End and the Sutro Baths, the beautiful ruins that we wish were still in tact! We will continue following the coastal trail along the cliffs, where jaw-dropping vistas promise a steady flow of hikers and runners. Take a breather (and an obligatory selfie) at the Eastern Coastal Trail Overlook, where we'll get your first look at the Golden Gate Bridge in all its glory. Then, keep following the Coastal Trail and veer north to the Eagle Point Labyrinth. Once we're back on the Coastal Trail, we'll pass through diverse plant life and past trails that branch off to Lincoln Park Golf Course and the Legion of Honor. The Land's End Trail will end at 32nd Avenue and El Camino Del Mar. Continuing on El Camino Del Mar, here we'll enter into a totally different terrain: The neighborhood of Sea Cliff, known for posh maisons. We will stay left on El Camino del Mar to continue onto Sea Cliff Avenue. If we turn left on 25th Avenue and keep right, we will see a small passage to Baker Beach. Climb the notorious Sand Ladder to Lincoln Blvd. to begin the Battery to Bluffs Trail on the left, which exposes stunning views of Sea Cliff, the Marin Headlands, and Baker Beach. You will pass by the Battery Crosby. The trail here is windy and steep with many stairs, but it blooms with coastal ground cover and offers some of most scenic landscapes in SF. At Battery Godfrey, an artillery platform built in 1895, climb the stairs on the right to the small park, where benches offer a welcome spot to take in the views of the Golden Gate. Next, walk down the stairs toward Storey Ave. to continue our way into the Presidio.
The Finish Line:
When we finally arrive at the Presidio Main Post Lawn, take off our shoes, cop a squat on the lawn, and give ourselves a pat on the back for conquering a seriously major urban hike. After the hike we have option to indulge at Transit Cafe (215 Lincoln Blvd.), is an indoor/outdoor must for easy grub, including breakfast burritos, salads, burgers and Neapolitan pies to eat in or take to go.
name: Urban Hike: Ocean Beach to the Presidio

description:
Please join us for a very special edition of Awakened Living Sunday!


Practitioners' Workshop

facilitated by Rebecca Farrar and TJ Woodward

An incredible morning of connection, healing and love.



Are you interested in experiencing different healing modalities?

Are you a holistic or spiritual practitioner looking to connect with other healers?

Are you looking to share ideas and experiences of working in a "helping" profession?

Workshop is open to all, so whether you are a holistic practitioner, or looking to connect with a group of powerful healers, this workshop will be a wonderful opportunity to come together and grow!

Sunday, May 31st

11:00 AM - 12:30 PM

Fort Mason Center - Building C - Room C205

THIS WORKSHOP WILL INCLUDE:

• Interactive processes


• Lively discussions


• Sharing of ideas and practices


• Demonstrations of healing modalities

PLEASE JOIN US!



Hosted By Awakened Living

Awakened Living is a 21st century movement for people who consider themselves spiritual, but not religious, and have a deep hunger for personal and global transformation.

We are a diverse group of like-minded people dedicated to joyous celebration, spiritual practice, and connected community.

In spiritual and religious communities, people are often told what to believe. Awakened Living is different because we do not rely on a dogma or a prescribed set of beliefs. We feel it is more valuable to ask the right questions rather than purport to have the correct answers.


www.AwakenedLivingSF.org

Rebecca Farrar

Rebecca is an astrologer who recently founded Tell 'em, a friend-based recommendation platform built to empower and connect holistic service providers. She has more than 10 years of experience working in communications including on-camera and print journalism, public relations, marketing, and community relations. In 2013, she completed her M.A. at the California Institute of Integral Studies in the Philosophy, Cosmology, and Consciousness program. Her thesis, titled "Stargazing: Re-enchantment Through Language," combines philology, consciousness studies, and enchantment with the stars.


Rebecca also describes herself as fairy-witch who believes in magic, mermaids, and unicorns. When not writing on her blog (www.wildwitchwest.com) she can be found taking pictures of the sidewalks of San Francisco, cuddling her cat, or wandering Ocean Beach.

www.rebeccafarrar.com

</a>

Author and Spiritual Teacher TJ Woodward

TJ Woodward is the minister and spiritual director of Awakened Living. In addition to serving in this role, he is an awakening coach and addiction counselor. TJ helps people profoundly change the way they exist, by equipping them with the internal resources to lead their lives intuitively, strategically, and intentionally. With over 25 years experience in the fields of human potential and addiction recovery, he brings a unique mix of skills and insights to his coaching practice, talks and workshops.

He is the author of the book Conscious BEING: Awakening to Your True Nature. Conscious BEING is an insightful guide for rediscovering your essential nature and living an intentional and awakened life.

<a href="http://www.ConsciousBEINGbook.com">www.ConsciousBEINGbook.com

www.tjwoodward.com

name: Practitioners' Workshop

description:
We'll hike about 5 miles in beautiful Annadel State Park. This place is a gem. You'll likely see wild turkeys, ducks, vultures, deer, and of course the lake.

The rating is moderate - depending on your condition, though easy for some (or is that sum?)

This is a combined event w/ other Meetup grps, so it will be an excellent opportunity to meet some new people.

Directions:

GPS [masked],[masked]


From Hwy 101 take Hwy 12 East and when it hits the street, keep going straight about 2 miles 'till it T's at Summerfield Dr. Turn Right there and go 3 blocks and turn Left on Carissa, which you'll follow up the hill to the clearing and park there.

What To Bring:

Vino and cups

Good Hiking Boots/shoes

Layered clothing, hat, sunscreen.

At least 1 liter of water (Fill your bladder/bottles 1/2 way and refrigerate the night before, then top off w/ ice in the a.m. and you'll have chilled water all day.

Vino/snacks for our pre-lunch break during the hike

Food and more food to share (dried fruit/nuts/seeds, chips, dips, salsa, deserts - be creative!)

Drinks - vino, beer, tea, whatever wets your whistle.

$5 activity fee

If you've been on any of my hikes you know what to expect. The vino is required to be a part of this hike... OK, not really, but it's always nice when the vino to hiker ratio is high!

Your sense of humour is an absolute must!
name: Sunday Saunter, Potluck, & General Insanity - Annadel State Park (Sonoma County)

description:
Busy with work? Stressed out at home? Come join us for a 6-hr art session with Linh Dang in San Carlos. You will be learning art techniques and how to use diverse medium for your art journaling, which helps improve problem-solving and cognitive thinking. For more details, see here: http://bit.ly/LFNArtjournal

15% off [with promotion code: LFNAFA] for any future classes you sign up from LFN!


This one day workshop is about playing with paint and learning techniques such as: painting papers, collage, binding a simple journal, doodling, creative lettering, collage using old books/magazines/papers, and layering with paint/stencils/stamps. This course emphasizes on equipping the students with a tool to improve their quality of life by providing a deep and rich experience through art journaling. Scientific evidence supports benefits for Art Journaling. Art Journaling clarifies your thoughts and feelings, reduces stress, and helps improve problem-solving as well as increasing cognitive thinking. Join us and learn a new tool for self-care while making new friends.

In this class you will experience:

• Being a part of a small class size in a safe, inspiring

• environment and pleasant atmosphere ready for creative play and adventure.

• Step-by-step demos to help you go through the processes

• Various techniques using stencils, stamps, gesso
Soul collage

• Collage methods of layering with paint

• Painting harmonizing backgrounds

• Mindful doodling
name: [LFN] 50 Shades of Art Journaling

Sundays for 3 hours: 10 am to 1 pm without instruction.
Doors open at 9:45 am for early set-up.

All mediums OK, except no turpentine or turpenoid. Gamsol OK.
Pay by the month at the $15 rate (per session), or pay at the
drop-in rate $20 per session.

Located at The Atelier School of Classical Realism, at 4930
Telegraph ave, near 51.st

intercom, move the handle to get in.

There are two spotlights coming from the same direction, above and in front of the model. The model poses from an elevated stage-platform, so that everyone gets an unobstructed line-of-sight.

Plentiful free parking is conveniently available along
Telegraph ave and the side streets (parking meters are not
applicable on Sundays)

Come and draw or paint with us, improve you skills and
technique or simply enjoy yourself rendering great models.

For more information contact Gabriel at:
[masked]

description:
We have decided to make this full-day workshop and connection opportunity FREE! (We'll pass a hat at the end for voluntary contributions.) Please join us for an exciting day of meeting growth-conscious lesbian and queer single women, and learning and practicing communicating & dating skills! See below for details :)

Single, and having trouble connecting with women you want to date? Or do you find yourself dating women who aren't right for you?


In this full day, highly experiential workshop, we’ll do lots of partner exercises that help you authentically connect with the other women in the room, while also preparing you for a deeper, more satisfying and more successful dating process.

We’ll help you practice key pre-dating and dating communication skills, like:

· Unlocking the mysteries of chemistry and compatibility – and learning what qualities your potential mate must have if you want a happy, lasting relationship.

· How to handle your fear of rejection and connect with women in an authentic, satisfying way, regardless of whether or not they’re a good match for you.,

· How to converse in ways that build appropriate levels of intimacy. (Most women either stay too distant, do an “self-revelation dump” that sabotages connection, or move too quickly into flirting/sexualized interaction, rather than developing true contact.)

· How to stay in your body and in touch with your own wants and needs during a date, while also finding out who the other woman really is!

Since this is a workshop for singles, you may be wondering, “Will there be women who are ‘my type’ at the workshop?”


Our answer is: while we can’t predict the ages, physical types or other specifics of the women who will show up, we can predict that the women who show up will be women who want meaningful connection, are frustrated with “dating as usual,” and are looking for a better way.

If sparks fly at the workshop, great! But we’d encourage you to consider the possibility that meeting like-minded women, getting clear about what to look for, and getting to practice having key dating conversations is just as important, if not more so!

So, you might meet someone at the workshop whom you’d like to date. Or, you might meet fellow travelers or friends who can support you on the conscious dating path. Either way, you’ll learn, have fun… and get closer to the love you want.


We'll meet from 10:00 a.m. - 6:00 p.m. and take a 75-minute break for lunch mid-day. You can bring a bag lunch and eat in the meeting space, or go out with new friends to one of the many restaurants and cafes in the area.

See you there :)

Limited to 34 women - so reserve your spot soon!
how_to_find_us: Just a few blocks from MacArthur BART! Second floor of the historic pink victorian building that houses Hooper's Chocolates
name: Free! Meet Conscious Les/Queer Singles & Learn Skills, Too

group.name: Conscious Girlfriend: For Happy, Healthy Lesbian/Queer Love

description:
The game of five stand and incredibly challenging shooting sport

Shooting from an elevated position you're shooting down and Across at targets movie in many different directions. This requires more thinking and planning out of each shot. The first one is a single target that you can take two shots at even if you break it with the second shot it still scores. The next two shots are called a report pair you call the first shot when you fire the sound of your fire is calling your second shot so you have to track two different targets at different speeds. The last two shots are called a true pair or two targets are launched from two different machines at the same time this requires you to be a little faster and more disciplined in your tracking. I totally find that the game of five stand is more fun than most of the other shooting games that I do
name: Shooting from the upper deck

description:
On Sunday, May 31st, women across the nation are gathering to enjoy a ride together on their local streets and trails to celebrate women in cycling. Whether you’re an accomplished mountain bike rider or a first-timer, Women’s Ride Day will help you connect with other women in your area who enjoy riding trails just as much as you!

RSVP on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/events/758843747546539/

SFUR and Mike’s are partnering to host our local edition of this event on Mt Sutro trails right here in SF. Rides of all skill levels will meet at Mike’s for coffee and snacks starting at 10 am, with rides leaving by 11 am. Mountain Bikes recommended: you can bring your own or try a demo bike from Mike’s Bikes.

Mike’s is generously providing a size run of Specialized Rumor bikes for demo at this event, for free! If you don’t have a bike for the event, please email [masked]
name: SF Urban Riders and Mike's Bikes: Women's Ride Day

description:
Lands End- Golden Gate National Recreation Area:

At the northwestern corner of San Francisco, there is a series of stunning views at every turn in this wild and windy trail. Hillsides of cypress and wildflowers, views of shipwrecks and access to the ruins of Sutro baths, a San Francisco specials memory.

Lands End Lookout

The Lands End Lookout is located on the coast at Point Lobos Avenue and Merrie Way. Situated directly above the Cliff House and overlooking the Sutro Bath ruins, the center offers awesome views and easy access to the amazing Lands End Trails.

It looks like this from the street:

Open daily from 9:00 am – 5:00 pm.
name: Wildflowers of the Coast-Lands End San Francisco

This is a Sunday on-going JKD/FMA/Martial Arts/Personal Defense workout Safety first is my primary rule.

To find the horseshoe pits, enter the park at the Stanyan Hayes Park entrance, follow the paved footpath until you reach the road. Turn right, walk up about a hundred yards and you will see a sign/staircase for the horseshoe pits.

Rain days are at the Chinese Pavilion (the gazebo on the Stowe Lake island just past the waterfall). It is a bit less muni friendly, but car parking should be available on the lake for those who travel that way.

In it's favor, the location has nearby bathrooms, it feels more martial artsy, it can handle eight, is covered, so no rained out. But more importantly, great acoustics. It's bothered me practicing Sonny's stuff without music, this place solves that.

I am going to start allowing folks to spar/play - a major gear-shift from the self-defense/combatives scenario approach I have used since I started organizing this group. It is strictly optional. I am going to require three classes before I let you play.

The distinction I am making here is spar = without weapons, play = with trainer-weapons - rattan is basically banned.

As always, no fight club, no dog brothers.

(Several of you have taken exception to my no dog brothers rule, implying, "we're not all idiots." After all, a guy trained by subject of a dog brother documentary, Sonny Umpad, and fracking punk-rock anarchist icon, Frank Discussion, should delight in training you to take out guys with batons in riot gear. Sadly, this is not the case.

The problem isn't the TFM or the dog-brothers, per say, the problem is its devotees tend to develop an attitude that becomes a problem. The dog brother attitude/approach makes it difficult for some rare individuals within their ranks and on their periphery to know why they are training. Of the three people I've kicked to the curb/banned from this group, two fell into that category. The third was a mentally disturbed registered sex offender.

Highly recommend watching the original Japanese "Shall we dance," movie if you are still a bit confused about what I will and will not accept behavioral-wise.

People of all levels and different Martial Arts systems are welcome to attend. I emphasize, safety first, movement, flow, with broken rhythm, basic techniques and JKD terminology/language.

For those of you who don't know, www.nextbus.com is a useful resource for getting around on Muni, but kinda sucks unless you already know what bus routes you need.

Gavin
how_to_find_us: The Horseshoe Pits are inside the park at the Stanyan Hayes entrance. Follow the asphalt to Conservatory Dr. W, turn right walk up the hill. Meetup's map is seemingly fixed. Who knows when.
name: JKD In the Park

description:
This is a pickup soccer game Sundays at 10 AM on the Marina Green, in the middle of the field, next to the small Ralston monument. There is always a game every Sunday even if you see only 1 RSVP on the list. There are "regular offline" players who are not part of this online meetup group. For any given Sunday we can add 10 to 20 "regular offline players" to the RSVP list.

All skill levels are welcome! Everybody who is friendly and has a good attitude, is welcome to come out and play. All you need to do is show up and play in a good manner. However, we're not liable for any injury or harm that may occur.


A $1 donation to the group would be appreciated at the pickup location. This is not a mandatory fee. The collected money will be used primarily towards maintaining the site and new balls when necessary. Again, this is not mandatory.

We usually do 'Color Shirts vs. White Shirts,' so bringing both will be great. Please do not bring any gray shirts. Please note we play with goalies; we do not take corner kicks.


Very important: We want to keep it safe for everyone, so rough plays and/or slide tackles are NOT allowed. Legitimate shoulder-to-shoulder contact is okay. See you all on the pitch!
how_to_find_us: Marina Green --
name: Pickup Soccer on the Marina Green

description:
Note: a limited number of need-based scholarships are available, as well as discounts for groups of 2 or more are available. Please see FAQs below for more information.


Come solidify your understanding of JavaScript functions, and learn the common mistakes made by beginners. This highly interactive course instills these JS fundamentals via classwork provided between lectures. You will work in pairs to complete the programming exercises.

Afterwards, you will have exercises and work to continue practicing once you leave the class. You will also have the opportunity to be part of a community for beginners studying JavaScript.

--- Agenda ---

10:00am Welcome & Introduction

10:15am Functions (review) & Scope

11:15am Exercises

12:00pm Lunch

12:30pm Closures

1:30pm Exercises

2:30pm Callbacks/Higher-Order Functions

3:15pm Exercises

3:45pm Underscore.js

4:30pm Exercises

5:30pm Debrief

--- FAQ ---

Am I at the right level for this class?

This class is for budding developers with at least 3 months of JavaScript experience and have completed our JavaScript Fundamentals workshop Part 1 (covering objects, arrays, and functions) and/or at least one or two online JavaScript tutorials like Codecademy or CodeSchool. Those with more experience also tend to get a lot out of this course. In other words, you should already be very comfortable with the basics of arrays, objects, looping, calling functions, and the "return" keyword.

How can I request a scholarship?

Please email [masked] with the following information:

• Your full name;

• A brief description of why you need a scholarship;

• A brief explanation of why you want to learn JavaScript.

Do I need to bring a laptop?

No, but you probably want to bring one if you can (for taking notes).

Do I need to apply to take this course?

No.

Will this help me get into MakerSquare?

JS Fundamentals is a two part series created to help you prepare to get into and succeed at MakerSquare; however there is no guarantee and taking this class has no impact on your admissions prospects.

Will food be provided?

Lunch, coffee and snacks will be provided.

Are group discounts available?

Yes! Groups should NOT RSVP via Meetup.com. Groups should email Rachel Jenkins at [masked] with the following information:

• The number of people in your group;

• The full names and email addresses of the people in your group.

The organizers will then contact groups directly to confirm attendance and arrange payment.

Pricing for groups:

2-3 people $185/person

4+ people $155/person

I can't make it this time. When will the next one be?

TBD. Sign up here to stay updated on workshop schedules and other events going on at MakerSquare.

Are there any options for remote attendance?

No. Unfortunately, you cannot attend remotely.

Where do I direct my other questions?

Please leave them in the comments below.
name: JavaScript Fundamentals Part 2: Scopes, Closures, Callbacks

description:
Nearby Fairfax there is a trail that has beautiful views of the Richmond bridge and the hills. It passes by Carson Falls, follows a creek and ends at Kent Lake. We'll meet in the small parking lot at the trail head and hike to the lake where we'll have a seated meditation and lunch by the calm and serene lake. In a field on our way back, Larissa will lead a creative and gentle yoga which is available to all levels.


The hike is about 8 miles with 1500 feet elevation gain. As always, please bring water, lunch, your yoga mat, sunscreen and whatever else will make you most comfortable on this journey. Unfortunately, the falls will not have much water at this time of year but the hike is beautiful and peaceful. There are areas of both sun & shade throughout the hike. The way down to the lake is very steep so where proper shoes.

Here is some more information about the hike with photos: http://gurmeet.net/hiking/hikes/Carson_Falls_Kent_Lake_Route_I.html

A $15 dana (donation) is greatly appreciated for yoga and hike facilitation. As always, it helps fund meetup fees and helps cultivate good karma! ;) It is a truly beautiful experience.

Directions to arrive to Parking lot from downtown Fairfax:

From US 101 in Marin County, exit San Anselmo/Sir Francis Drake. Drive about 5 miles west on Sir Francis Drake to Fairfax. Turn left on Pastori, right on Broadway, and left onto Fairfax-Bolinas Road. Drive about 4 miles on Fairfax-Bolinas Road to the parking lot on the left side of the road.
Spots to watch out for on Fairfax-Bolinas Road: there will be a fork in the road to enter Bon Tempe lake, bear to the right in order to continue on Bolinas-Fairfax Rd for 1.5 miles. You will pass a golf course on your left, about .5 miles up the hill will be a parking lot on the left side that fits about 20 cars. The parking lot is on the top of the hill, if you start to go downhill again--you've driven too far. The trailhead is across the street but we'll meet in the parking lot.

Google maps link: https://maps.google.com/maps?q=37.963486,-122.624888&sll=37.957681,-122.629528&sspn=0.032473,0.019431&num=1&t=h&z=17

Join our Facebook Community: www.facebook.com/2livefreely
name: Carson Falls & Kent Lake: Hike, Yoga, Meditate
